item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Alcoholic Liver Disease
item.description:
A progressive liver disorder caused by chronic alcohol consumption, leading to liver inflammation, fatty liver, fibrosis, and cirrhosis.


Early Stage (Fatty Liver/Steatosis): Often asymptomatic, hepatomegaly, mild elevation in liver enzymes
Alcoholic Hepatitis: Jaundice, RUQ pain, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, fever, hepatomegaly, ascites
Cirrhosis (Late Stage): Portal hypertension, ascites, varices, hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, muscle wasting
Portal Hypertension - causes ascites; blood pressure in the liver’s veins gets so high, it starts causing swollen belly and bleeding


LFT (AST, ALT) → AST > ALT (usually 2:1 ratio)**
Elevated GGT, Bilirubin, INR (if liver dysfunction severe)
Low Albumin (liver can't synthesize proteins)
Abdominal Ultrasound/CT (fatty infiltration, cirrhosis signs)
Liver Biopsy (definitive diagnosis if needed)


Chronic excessive alcohol intake (typically > 40g/day for men, > 20g/day for women)
Genetic predisposition
Malnutrition (common in heavy drinkers)


Heavy, prolonged alcohol use
Female sex (higher susceptibility to alcohol-induced damage)
Genetic polymorphisms affecting alcohol metabolism
Hepatitis C coinfection
Obesity (worsens liver damage)
Poor nutrition (low protein, vitamin deficiencies)


Jaundice (yellow skin/eyes)
Fatigue
Abdominal pain or discomfort
Nausea and vomiting
Ascites (swelling in the abdomen)
Easy bruising or bleeding
Hepatic encephalopathy (confusion, altered mental state)
Spider veins on the skin
Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly)
Dark urine and pale stools


CNS: Hepatic encephalopathy (confusion, asterixis, coma)
GI: Esophageal varices, GI bleeding, pancreatitis
Cardiovascular: Cardiomyopathy, hypertension
Renal: Hepatorenal syndrome (kidney failure due to liver dysfunction)


Liver failure (irreversible damage)
Hepatic encephalopathy (toxin buildup, confusion, coma)
Esophageal varices (rupture → massive GI bleed)
Hepatocellular carcinoma (increased risk with cirrhosis)


Alcohol cessation (most important intervention)
Nutritional support (high-protein diet, vitamin supplementation, especially thiamine to prevent Wernicke’s encephalopathy)
Corticosteroids (for severe alcoholic hepatitis)
Pentoxifylline (may reduce inflammation, used in severe cases)
Liver transplant (for end-stage cirrhosis in select patients)


Monitor liver function tests, coagulation studies
Assess for withdrawal symptoms (tremors, agitation, seizures, delirium tremens)
Encourage alcohol rehabilitation programs
Manage ascites (fluid restriction, diuretics, paracentesis if needed)
Monitor for GI bleeding (black stools, hematemesis)
Educate on alcohol abstinence, nutrition, and follow-up care
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cirrhosis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
Note difference between Liver Failure & Cirrhosis
Liver Failure - loss of liver function caused by damage from drugs, infection, or cirrhosis


late-stage condition that presents with advanced fibrosis or scarring of the liver = impaired liver function
irreversible but can be slowed with treatment
can be compensated or non-compensated
compensated - liver has compensated and continues to make corrections accordingly with no external indications of the disorder
non-compensated - presents with ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, GI bleed jaundice


alcohol abuse
Hepatitis BCD
NAFLD, NASH
genetic
bile duct disease
meds


obesity, diabetes, age, family hx
exposure to toxins or chemicals
meds that affect liver


jaundice of eyes and skin
N/V
abdominal pain, swelling
increased bruising
lower extremity edema
spider angioma - spiderlike veins on skin
weight loss or muscle wasting
pruritus (caused by buildup of bile salts)
hepatic encephalopathy
Ascites - fluid in peritoneal cavity
severe: confusion, drowsiness, personality change (indicates hepatic encephalopathy)
Portal Hypertension - causes ascites; blood pressure in the liver’s veins gets so high, it starts causing swollen belly and bleeding


fluid in peritoneal cavity may lead to pulmonary complications, hernias, Med-Surg I/GI/Peritonitis, sepsis
Variceal Rupture - a life-threatening condition that occurs when abnormally enlarged veins in the esophagus or stomach burst and bleed
Ammonia build-up leading to Cerebral Edema and ultimately increased ICP
Hepatic encephalopathy: A decline in brain function due to the liver's inability to remove toxins, leading to confusion, drowsiness, and even coma.
Coagulopathy - cant stop bleeding
liver cancer
infections - from Med-Surg I/GI/Peritonitis


CBC - r/o anemia/internal bleeding
Imaging - MRI, US, CT
Elastography - noninvasive scanes to check fibrosis


treat cause (see Hepatitis)
edema/ascites - diuretics
Lactulose - reduce ammonia levels, encephalopathy
Betablockers - portal hypertension
Vit K & FFP = coagulopathy
Parecentesis - remove fluid from ascites
Cancer treatment
Surgery - ligation of varices


monitor bleeding / shock - from variceal rupture
check weight d/t edema, ascites
check abdominal girth
observe LOC (Hepatic Encephalopathy)
low Na diet
monitor LFT


Risk for Bleeding: Due to impaired clotting factor production.
Fluid Volume Excess: Caused by ascites and edema from portal hypertension.
Imbalanced Nutrition: Less than Body Requirements: Due to reduced appetite, malabsorption, and metabolic changes.
Risk for Infection: Due to compromised immune function and potential for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
Acute Pain: Related to liver inflammation or distension from ascites.
Disturbed Thought Processes: From hepatic encephalopathy caused by toxin buildup.
Fatigue: Due to decreased liver function and overall metabolic disturbances.
Impaired Skin Integrity: Related to pruritus, ascites, or jaundice.
Impaired Liver Function: Related to ongoing liver damage.
Anxiety: Due to chronic illness and concerns about disease progression.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Fatty Liver - Steatotic Liver Disease
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal


fat accumulation in liver due to metabolic dysfunction
usually a benign, reversible condition curable with lifestyle mods but can progress to Cirrhosis
2 Types: NAFLD, Alcoholic Liver Disease => (only difference is alcohol)
Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD):

Metabolic dysfunction (e.g., obesity, insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, high cholesterol, hypertension)
Poor diet (high-fat, high-sugar foods)
Sedentary lifestyle
Genetic factors
Certain medications (e.g., corticosteroids, methotrexate, tamoxifen)
Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (ALD): see Alcoholic Liver Disease

Chronic alcohol consumption
Toxic effects of alcohol on liver metabolism


Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD):
Obesity
Type 2 diabetes
High cholesterol or triglycerides
High blood pressure
Metabolic syndrome
Older age
Family history of liver disease
Poor diet (high in processed foods, sugar, or fats)
Sedentary lifestyle
Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (ALD):
Excessive alcohol consumption
Heavy drinking over long periods
Male gender (more common in men, though women can develop ALD at lower alcohol levels)

Early stages may be asymptomatic.
Possible symptoms include:
Fatigue
Weight loss or difficulty losing weight
Abdominal discomfort (especially in the right upper quadrant)
Jaundice (in advanced stages)
Swelling in the abdomen or legs (in cases with liver damage)
Dark urine
Nausea or loss of appetite


Physical examination (may reveal hepatomegaly, or liver enlargement)
Blood tests:
Elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT)
Lipid profile (elevated cholesterol or triglycerides)
Fasting blood glucose (to assess for insulin resistance)
Ultrasound: Most common test to identify fatty liver
CT scan or MRI: Can provide a more detailed view of the liver
Liver biopsy: May be needed in cases of Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH) to assess liver damage
Elastography: Measures liver stiffness to evaluate for fibrosis or cirrhosis


Lifestyle changes:
Weight loss (gradual, about 1-2 lbs per week)
Dietary modifications (low-fat, low-sugar, and nutrient-dense diet)
Exercise (at least 30 minutes of moderate activity, 5 days a week)
Avoid alcohol (for ALD and NAFLD patients)
Medications (mainly for managing underlying conditions):
Insulin sensitizers (e.g., metformin for insulin resistance)
Statins for high cholesterol
Vitamin E (in some cases of NASH)
Liver transplant: In severe cases of cirrhosis due to fatty liver
Manage comorbidities:
Control diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia
Avoid hepatotoxic medications (e.g., acetaminophen in high doses)

Monitor liver function:
Regularly check liver enzymes (AST, ALT) and bilirubin levels.
Monitor blood glucose and lipid profile for associated metabolic conditions.
Diet and weight management:
Provide education on a low-fat, low-sugar diet and the importance of gradual weight loss.
Encourage physical activity and healthy eating habits.
Patient education:
Alcohol cessation for those with ALD.
Educate about the long-term effects of untreated fatty liver (risk for cirrhosis).
Supportive care:
Manage fatigue and any discomfort associated with the liver enlargement.
Provide emotional support for weight loss challenges and lifestyle changes.
Monitor for complications:
Watch for signs of progression to cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, ascites, easy bruising).
Watch for signs of hepatic encephalopathy in advanced stages (confusion, altered mental status).

item.title: Hepatitis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal


inflammation of the liver


Viral hepatitis: Caused by Hep ABCDE
Autoimmune hepatitis: Immune system attacks liver cells (less common)
Toxic hepatitis: Due to alcohol, drugs, or toxins. (less common)
Metabolic hepatitis: Related to fatty liver diseases (e.g., MASLD).
constant irritation causes cells to necrotize and eventually form scar tissues => Cirrhosis(complication)
Hepatitis Virus - ABCDE

most common: ABC
A = ass to mouth (oral-fecal)
B & C = blood and cum (bloodborne & sexual transmission)
D = double dip (needs B infection first)
E = exit through the ass (oral-fecal)


vary depending on type
A & E- poor sanitation, oral-fecal route, close contact, drug use, seggs, travel to endemic areas, contaminated food
B - unprotected seggs, multiple partners (ho life), needles, mother to child, healthcare workers, tattoos, close proximity
C = same as B, lower risk from seggs
Common risk factors: older adults, immunocompromised, alcohol abuse, preexisting liver conditions


jaundice of eyes and skin = buildup of bilirubin
N/V
abdominal pain, swelling
fever, fatigue, loss of appetite
dark urine = bilirubin in urine
clay-colored stool (white or gray shit => lack of bile = no bilirubin as it is normally excreted in stool)
pruritus - buildup of bile salts in skin
muscle/joint pain = B/C
SEVERE: significant weight loss, uncontrolled N/V, confusion/drowsiness, bruising easily, severe abdominal pain


Cirrhosis => read this as these two are related
Liver Failure
fulminant liver failure - hepatic encephalopathy, occurs abruptly
Bleeding disorders - coagulopathy (Vitamin K is stored and activated in liver)
liver cancer
hepatic encephalopathy - severe; toxins cannot be excreted by liver
Portal Hypertension
a lot more


LFT = elevated
serum antibodies to specify which type => guides treatment decisions
Imaging: US, CT, MRI
Liver biopsy
Elastography - noninvasive alternative to biopsy that measures liver stiffness (stiff = fibrosis)
Coags = liver is responsible for clotting factors


Hepatitis A = no treatment; supportive care only; resolves on its own
B & C = interferon for 6 months (proteins produced naturally by immune system for viruses)
Direct Acting Antivirals = Hep C
not allowed: alcohol, tylenol


risk for malnutrition (sarcopenia = loss of muscle from low protein intake)
encourage smaller more frequent meals to reduce upset stomach
Ascites = compute caloric calculations with ideal weight instead of including ascites weight
risk for hyponatremia = very common
risk for thrombocytopenia = low platelets, BLEEDING PRECAUTIONS, no shaving, no hard-bristle toothbrush or dental floss, no aspirin/NSAID, check for signs of bleeding, falls precautions
Educate on diet
encourage vaccination
encourage handwashing
no seggs
use needleless systems if possible
report all cases of virus to health department


Chronic Liver Disease - umbrella term that includes hepatitis, steatotic liver disease (SLD), cirrhosis, carcinoma, liver failure
Steatotic Liver Disease - aka Fatty Liver - Steatotic Liver Disease, also includes alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD), metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), and MetALD (a combination of MASLD and ALD).​​​​​​​


Risk for Bleeding: Impaired liver function reduces clotting factors, increasing bleeding risk.
Fluid Volume Excess: Ascites and edema from portal hypertension and decreased albumin.
Imbalanced Nutrition: Less than Body Requirements: Inadequate intake and malabsorption due to liver dysfunction.
Risk for Infection: Impaired immune function and potential for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) in cirrhosis.
Acute Pain: Abdominal discomfort from liver inflammation, ascites, or liver capsule distension.
Disturbed Thought Processes: Hepatic encephalopathy from toxin buildup affecting brain function.
Fatigue: Decreased liver function and metabolic changes cause physical exhaustion.
Impaired Skin Integrity: Risk of skin breakdown from edema, pruritus, or jaundice.
Risk for Impaired Liver Function: Further liver damage due to ongoing inflammation, alcohol, or medication use.
Anxiety: Psychological stress from chronic illness, uncertainty, and potential complications.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Bowel Obstruction
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
What is it:

Blockage in the intestines preventing normal passage of food, gas, and fluid
can be partial, complete, occurring in SMALL or LARGE intestine
Causes:

Mechanical: Tumors, adhesions (scar tissue), hernias, volvulus (twisted bowel), impacted stool, diverticulitis
Non-mechanical (paralytic ileus): Loss of normal bowel movement due to nerve or muscle problems (e.g., after surgery, electrolyte imbalances).
Risk Factors: Previous abdominal surgery (adhesions), cancer/tumors, Crohn's, hernias, constipation, old
Clinical Manifestations: abdominal pain, bloating/distention, NO BOWEL SOUNDS, vomiting (can smell like shit), constipation, dehydration, e- imbalance
Diagnosis: CXR/CT, CBC to r/o infection, BMP for e- imbalances, U/S for peds
Treatment: NPO, IVF, NGT decompression, Analgesia, antiemetics, surgery if severe or caused by tumor
Nursing Considerations: always check bowel sounds,



blockage of LARGE intestine
prevents normal passage of stool and gas
leads to bowel distention, fluid shifts, and ischemia
can be mechanical or functional (see causes)


mechanical: tumors, diverticulitis, volvulus, hernias, strictures, adhesions, impacted feces
functional: paralytic ileus, neurogenic disorders, post-op complications (see Gastroparesis)


hx of abdominal surgery
colorectal cancer
diverticular disease
chronic constipation
narcotic use
old age
neuro deficit affecting motility


distension
cramping pain (intermittent if mechanical, constant if ischemic)
N/V
constipation
high pitched bowel sounds (early)
absent bowel sounds (late)


XR, CT, contrast enema
colonoscopy of not acutely obstructed


NPO
IVF, e- correction
NGT decompression
Analgesia
surgery if severe: stent, tumor resection, colostomy


always assess bowel sounds, distention, pain
NGT decompression
pain control without opioids if possible



same as large bowel but for SMALL (lol)


mechanical: adhesions (most common), hernias, tumors, vovulus, intussusception, strictures, foreign bodies
functional: paralytic ileus, postop complications, infections, nuro
adhesions - bands of scar tissue that form between intestines and other organs
intussusception - one part of the intestine telescopes into another, similar to a collapsed telescope
strictures - narrowing of gi tract
volvulus - twisted intestines


previous abdominal surgeries
hernias,
hx of tumors
IBD
radiation therapy, opioid use
old


same as LBO


same as LBO


same as LBO
adhesiolysis
hernia repair


same as LBO
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Celiac's Disease
item.description:
What is it: Autoimmune disorder where eating gluten (found in wheat, barley, and rye) damages the small intestine, leading to nutrient malabsorption.
Causes: genetics, triggered by gluten
Risk Factors: genetics, autoimmune diseases (Diabetes T1, thyroid), european descent, hx of digestive issues
Clinical Manifestations: Diarrhea, weight loss (d/t inability to absorb nutrients), bloating, abdominal pain, fatigue, iron-deficiency anemia, delayed growth in children, skin rashes (dermatitis herpetiformis).
Diagnosis: Blood tests (anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody), endoscopy with biopsy showing villous atrophy in the small intestine.
Treatment: strict gluten-free diet (lifelong)
Nursing Considerations: educate on food labels and meal planning, monitor for malnutrition, emotional support
Complications: osteoporosis, infertility
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Diverticulitis
item.description:
What is it: little pockets in your gut that get inflamed (diverticula) that form in the walls of the colon, typically in the sigmoid colon, occur in areas of weakness along the intestinal tract
Causes: Fecal matter or bacteria becoming trapped in the diverticula, leading to inflammation or infection
Risk Factors: constant straining (chronic constipation) => more pressure, age, obesity, smoking, lack of exercise, low fiber diet, steroids, opioids, NSAIDS
Clinical Manifestations: abdominal pain, fever, N/V, bloating, tenderness, possible rectal bleeding
Diagnosis: CT, CBC (infection), colonoscopy (r/o other conditions)
Treatment: abx, NPO (bowel rest) followed by clear liquid diet, Analgesia but no NSAIDS, surgery for complications (perforations, abscess, fistulas)


avoid NSAIDS
assess bowel sounds
hydrate
avoid enemas and laxatives during inflammation
avoid seeds, nuts, popcorn
if no inflammation, high fiber diet is encouraged


Nuts and Seeds: These can get trapped in the diverticula and cause irritation or infection (though current research suggests this may not always be true for everyone).
Popcorn: Similar to nuts and seeds, popcorn kernels can irritate diverticula.
Corn: Whole kernels can potentially get stuck in diverticula and cause issues.
Fruits and Vegetables with Small Seeds: Such as strawberries, raspberries, and tomatoes, which might irritate the diverticula.
Spicy Foods: Can irritate the digestive tract and increase inflammation.
High-Fat Foods: Fried foods, fatty meats, and full-fat dairy can slow digestion and worsen symptoms.
Refined Grains: White bread, pasta, and rice lack fiber and may worsen constipation, increasing pressure on the colon.
Processed Meats: Bacon, sausage, and other high-fat, processed meats can contribute to inflammation.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Irritable Bowel Diseases
item.description:
What is it: classified under the umbrella term known as an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
may demonstrate patches of inflammation followed by patches of healthy tissue
Causes: Exact cause unknown; likely involves immune system dysfunction, genetic predisposition, and environmental triggers.
Risk Factors: Family history, smoking, high-fat diet, NSAID use, stress, and exposure to Westernized diet/lifestyle.
Clinical Manifestations: Abdominal pain (usually RLQ), chronic diarrhea (sometimes bloody), weight loss, fatigue, malnutrition, fever, oral ulcers, and perianal disease (fissures, abscesses, fistulas).
Diagnosis: colonoscopy with biopsy, CT, MRI, fecal calprotectin (inflammation marker), blood tests (elevated CRP, anemia, vitamin deficiencies).
Treatment: Anti-inflammatory meds (5-ASA, corticosteroids), immunosuppressants (azathioprine, methotrexate), biologics (TNF inhibitors like infliximab), antibiotics for infections, surgery if complications arise (resections, fistula repair).
Nursing Considerations: Monitor for malnutrition, dehydration, electrolyte imbalances; provide dietary support (low-fiber during flares, high-calorie/protein intake); assess for medication side effects (infection risk with immunosuppressants); encourage smoking cessation and stress management. Watch for complications like strictures, perforation, and abscesses.


What is it: also under IBD, continuous inflammation and ulcers in the colon and rectum.
Causes: Unknown; thought to involve genetic, immune, and environmental factors.
Risk Factors: Family history, autoimmune disorders, high-fat diet, smoking (increased risk in non-smokers).
Clinical Manifestations: cramping, urgency, tenesmus, weight loss, fatigue, fever, anemia, sores can bleed = bloody diarrhea
Diagnosis: Colonoscopy with biopsy (shows continuous inflammation, ulcers), stool tests, blood tests (elevated CRP, anemia).
Treatment: Anti-inflammatory meds (5-ASA), corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, biologics (TNF inhibitors), surgery (colectomy if severe).
Nursing Considerations: Monitor for dehydration, malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances. Assess for complications (toxic megacolon, perforation).
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cholecystitis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal #cholecystitis
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal #cholecystitis

What is it: Inflammation of the gallbladder; can be calculous (gallstone) or acalculous
CALCULOUS

most common; gallbladder becomes inflamed due to an obstruction caused by a gallstone that may prevent the bile from being expelled
ACALCULOUS

sudden inflammation of the gallbladder w/o gallstones
more life threatening! high risk of perforation and necrosis that occurs more often in critically ill clients
dysfunction of the gallbladder emptying mechanism related to prolonged periods without oral feeding
usually accompanied by severe trauma, burns, sepsis or other major complication
Causes:

gallstones (calculous cholecystitis) obstructing the cystic duct, leading to bile stasis and infection
bacterial infection, ischemia, trauma, prolonged fasting, critical illness.
Risk Factors: Female, obesity, high-fat diet, rapid weight loss, pregnancy, hormone therapy, older age, diabetes, prolonged TPN use.
Clinical Manifestations: RUQ pain, radiates to right shoulder, worsens after fatty meals, N/V, fever, tachycardia, Murphy’s sign positive, possible jaundice if bile duct obstructed.
Diagnosis: Ultrasound (first-line), HIDA scan, CT scan, elevated WBC, LFTs (bilirubin, ALP), amylase/lipase if pancreatic involvement.
Treatment:

NPO
IV fluids
Analgesia
abx
cholecystectomy (laparoscopic preferred) - The surgical excision of the gallbladder.
ERCP if bile duct obstruction present.
Nursing Considerations:

Monitor for infection
pain control
NPO status
IV hydration
post-op care after cholecystectomy (early ambulation, wound care
educate on diet modifications (low-fat, small meals).
Things to note:
Murphy's Sign - when you press on the RUQ and the patient experiences pain
ERCP - Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography; a medical procedure that combines endoscopy and X-rays to diagnose and treat conditions affecting the bile ducts
ERCP is used to remove gallstones
MRCP - Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography, another imaging procedure
Estrogen - fucks up the gallbladder resulting in decreased production of bile salts => clumping of bile => blockage
HIDA scan - dye is injected to trace movement in bile ducts, Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid Scan, uses special camera

What is it: gallstones formed from cholesterol, bilirubin, or mixed substances in the gallbladder, can be asymptomatic or cause obstruction leading to cholecystitis.
Causes: Imbalance in bile composition (excess cholesterol, bilirubin, or decreased bile salts), bile stasis, gallbladder motility issues.
Risk Factors: Female, obesity, high-fat/low-fiber diet, rapid weight loss, pregnancy, hormone therapy, older age, diabetes, liver disease, prolonged TPN.
Clinical Manifestations: Asymptomatic or biliary colic (RUQ pain, radiates to right shoulder, postprandial, especially after fatty meals), nausea, vomiting, bloating, dyspepsia.
Diagnosis: Ultrasound (first-line), CT scan, MRCP, elevated LFTs if bile duct obstruction, ERCP if common bile duct stones suspected.
Treatment: Asymptomatic—no treatment needed; symptomatic—cholecystectomy (laparoscopic preferred), bile acid dissolution therapy (ursodiol) if surgery contraindicated, ERCP for bile duct stones.
Nursing Considerations: Pain management, monitor for signs of obstruction or infection, educate on diet changes (low-fat, small meals), post-op care after cholecystectomy, assess for complications like pancreatitis or cholangitis.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Gastric Ulcers
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
note: Ulcerative Colitis is different from Gastric Ulcers
see Irritable Bowel Diseases for Ulcerative Colitis

Location: Gastric ulcer affects the stomach; ulcerative colitis affects the colon and rectum.
Cause: Gastric ulcer is mainly due to acid damage; ulcerative colitis is an autoimmune condition.
Symptoms: Gastric ulcer pain is meal-related; ulcerative colitis presents with chronic diarrhea and blood in stool.
Treatment Approach: Gastric ulcer focuses on acid suppression; ulcerative colitis requires immune modulation.


open sores that occur in the inner lining of the stomach
ATI says they are synonymous with PEPTIC ULCERS or PUD
damaged protective mucosa is exposed to gastric juices => stomach tissue is dissolved (severe pain)
H. pylori colonizes mucosa causing inflammation and increased acidity


H.Pylori Infection
NSAID use
lifestyle: smoking, alcohol
cystic fibrosis, hyperparathyroidism, Zollinger Ellison
rare: viral infections chemo, cronhs, gastric/lung cancers, vascular insufficiencies


family history
liver, kidney or lung disease
Blood type O
rheumatoid arthritis


abdominal pain: burning sensation, gnawing = after meals or at night (due to acid irritating the ulcer)
weight loss, nausea, vomiting, feeling bloated, and early satiety


perforation - biggest concern as it can cause bleeding and infection
bleeding late signs: hypotension, tachycardia, dizziness, lightheadedness, weakness, SOB, bloody emesis or stool, anemia
fever from infection


CBC, LFT
EGD: gold standard, sedated procedure to obtain tissue biopsy, scope down your throat
test for H. Pylori = breath test or rapid urease test (biopsies placed in solution)
fecal antigen test
blood culture - also detects h.pylori
Detect perforation: CXR, contrast dye


PPI and H2 Blockers
change NSAID meds
prostaglandin analog (misoprostol) - reduce gastric acid secretion, increase mucus production
For H.Pylori infections: abx + PPI
Vagotomy = for severe cases
partial gastrectomy


spicy food - irritant
caffeine - increases stomach acid
alcohol - irritant
high acid foods: tomatoes, citrus, vinegar, pickled
chocolate
fatty: fried, fatty meat, full-fat dairy
peppermint: relaxes LES
carbonated beverages


educate NSAID use
monitor bloody stool or emesis
auscultate/inspect/palpate abdomen

item.title: Gastritis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal #gastritis
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal #gastritis


stomach is fucked up from alcohol, bad food, stress making it burn like hell
inflammation of the inner lining of the stomach that causes exposure to viruses, fungi, bacteria (H. Pylori)
can be an acute or chronic
multiple causes


Diet: over consumption of alcohol; eating spicy, fried, or acidic foods
NSAID use
infections - H. Pylori Infection (more common in poor or unsanitary communities)
stress (Stress-Induced Gastritis = an actual diagnosis)
smoking


being critically ill (burns, severe trauma, increased ICP, sepsis, organ failure) => prophylaxis of PPI PPI and H2 Blockers


loss of appetite, bloating
increased belching
nausea/vomiting
abdominal pain of the epigastric region
rare but possible: black, tarry stools and blood in their emesis


Gastric Ulcers
Gastric cancers


CBC to check for anemia (r/o bleeding) or WBC elevation
LFT, CMP, pancreas
stool sample
EGD: gold standard, sedated procedure to obtain tissue biopsy, scope down your throat
Urea Breath Test - detects H.Pylori presence
CT


PPI and H2 Blockers
metronidazole (Flagyl) => for h.pylori


educate: NSAID use
educate: hand hygiene
complete abx course
decrease stress
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Gastroparesis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal


stomach muscles don't work properly coz your nerves are fucked up
aka, gastropathy; "paralysis of stomach muscles"
affects movement of the muscles of the stomach caused by neurological dysfunction
chronic disorder that results in the delay or even absence of gastric emptying
food can harden in stomach because of lack of stomach movement


damage to the vagus nerve
usually complication of other diseases that affect the nerves
Diabetes: #1 cause (chronic high blood sugar levels can damage the vagus nerve)
other examples: surgery complications, autoimmune diseases, MS, hypothyroidism, stroke, myasthenia gravis, Parkinson's
side effects of meds: opioids, CCBs, marijuana, tricyclic antidepressants


long term use of opioids and antidepressants
cytomegalovirus, eppestein-barr, varicella, chagas
anorexia, bulimia


early satiety, bloating
nausea, vomiting
abdominal pain
acid reflux, decrease in level of energy, lack of appetite, or weight loss.


Gastric emptying test (Scintigraphy) = gold standard, xray with dyes; to trace how fast food is moved from stomach
EGD - esophagogastroduodenoscopy - tube with camera; most common =>sedated procedure
gastric emptying breath test (GEBT) - noninvasive, no radiation


antidopaminergic agents: Reglan, Motilium, stimulate muscles of GI tract
abx - promotes gastric emptying
antiemetics - zofran/odanzetron


diabetes patients: can go into DKA or HHS
palpate abdomen for distention
encourage more fluids (higher risk of dehydration)
encourage lifestyle mods

item.title: GERD
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal


stomach acids travels up esophagus, irritates lining
common chronic disease that affects daily life
lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is weakened and fails to close tightly to prevent backflow of stomach contents


diet: spicy, caffeine, high fat
irritants from smoking
obesity = increased intra-abdominal pressure ; promotes reflux
decreased physical activity
50 years or older or low socioeconomic status
excessive alcohol or caffeine consumption
lying down after eating


Hiatal Hernia
pregnant
Helicobacter pylori - bacterial infection that attacks the lining of the stomach and duodenum
stress
connective tissue disorders
medications: NSAIDS, anticholinergics, aspirin


irritation of the throat, or chest pain
contributes to heart burn = discomfort
regurgitation; sour taste in mouth
frequent belching, bloating, regurgitation
tooth decay: if it's chronic


Barrett’s esophagus - leads to esophageal cancer; lining of the esophagus changes from normal tissue to tissue that resembles the lining of the small intestine
dysphagia - difficulty swallowing
dyspepsia - epigastric pain
odynophagia - Painful swallowing.
tooth decay - acid erodes enamel of teeth


rule out chest pain from GI vs cardiac etiology; check comorbidities: hx, HTN, HLD, CAD, HF
EGD - esophagogastroduodenoscopy; tube with camera that goes down the throat
check pH in esophagus: ambulatory pH monitoring or an esophageal pH monitoring test
capsule test: capsule is left in esophagus to check pH content


PPI and H2 Blockers
H2 Blockers: cimetidine or famotidine
PPI: pantoprazole or omeprazole
Antacids: treat symptoms, neutralize acid
Surgery: endoscopic dilation, reinforce LES
possible NGT placement: for parenteral nutrition (liquid only)


spicy food - irritant
caffeine - increases stomach acid
alcohol - irritant
high acid foods: tomatoes, citrus, vinegar, pickled
chocolate
fatty: fried, fatty meat, full-fat dairy
peppermint: relaxes LES
carbonated beverages


educate on lifestyle changes: weight, exercise
avoid tight fitting clothes
stop smoking
avoid food triggers
meals 3 hrs before bedtime
raise head of bed 6-9 inches
maintain good oral hygiene

item.title: GI Bleed
item.description:
Bleeding from the esophagus, stomach, or duodenum, caused by mucosal damage, vascular lesions, or varices, leading to hematemesis or melena.


Peptic ulcer disease (most common) => see Gastric Ulcers
esophageal varices - enlarged, swollen veins in the lower esophagus
Gastritis
Mallory-Weiss tear - tear in esophagus from forceful coughing, vomiting
esophagitis
gastric cancer
angiodysplasia
NSAID or corticosteroid use.


H. pylori infection
chronic NSAID use
lifestyle: alcohol abuse, smoking
liver disease (cirrhosis) => see Hepatitis
anticoagulant therapy
stress ulcers (ICU patients)
history of GI bleed.


Hematemesis (bright red or coffee-ground)
melena (black, tarry stool)
epigastric pain
signs of shock: dizziness, hypotension, tachycardia, pallor, syncope, decreased UOP


CBC - check Hgb, Hct
Coags
LFT
endoscopy - gold standard
nasogastric lavage
BUN elevation

IV fluids, blood transfusion if needed, PPI and H2 Blockers (IV pantoprazole), endoscopic interventions (cauterization, clipping, banding), vasopressin or octreotide for variceal bleeding, surgery if uncontrolled.


Monitor vital signs for hypovolemia
assess stool/emesis for blood
maintain NPO status before endoscopy
administer IV fluids and medications
monitor for rebleeding
educate on avoiding NSAIDs, alcohol, and smoking.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hiatal Hernia
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal


upper part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm into the chest
increased intra-abdominal pressure pushes the stomach up
very common among 50+
2 types: sliding and paraesophageal hernias
Sliding - most common

occur when the upper section of the stomach occasionally slides up or protrudes into the chest area through the hiatus
Paraesophageal (PEH) - more advanced; can become an emergency

a greater portion of the stomach, a part of the esophagus, or perhaps the intestines have migrated up into the chest cavity through the hiatus.


anything that elevates intra-abdominal pressure
multiple pregnancies
skeletal disorders with bone decalcification and degeneration
constant bearing down: constipation or COPD


old age, 50+ (d/t weakened abdominal muscles)
GERD
obesity
pregnant
smoker


All GERD symptoms: heartburn, regurgitation, sour taste, etc
Water brash: excessive salivation, acidic taste
Post-prandial fullness - uncomfortable feeling of fullness in the stomach that persists after eating
bloating, early satiety
dysphagia
Severe: GI bleed = black tarry stool (melena)
Very severe: pulmonary symptoms if stomach presses on lungs: dyspnea and possibly atelectasis


esophageal compression
intestinal obstruction
GI Bleed= hematochezia (red blood stool), melena (black stool)
Anemia from bleeds: fatigue, SOB
gastric strangulation = tangled intestines (gastric volvulus)


X-ray
EGD - esophagogastroduodenoscopy - tube with camera; most common =>sedated procedure; biopsy samples taken
esophageal motility study - measures the strength and maneuverability of the muscles by inserting a catheter in esophagus
ambulatory esophageal reflux monitoring test (see GERD )


PPI and H2 Blockers
H2 Blockers: cimetidine or famotidine
PPI: pantoprazole or omeprazole
Antacids: treat symptoms, neutralize acid
surgical: laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication => wrapping the upper part of the stomach around the lower esophagus


Risk for Aspiration – Due to gastric contents refluxing into the esophagus, increasing the risk of aspiration pneumonia.
Acute Pain – Related to esophageal irritation from acid reflux, often presenting as heartburn or chest discomfort.
Impaired Swallowing – Due to esophageal compression or inflammation from chronic reflux.
Imbalanced Nutrition: Less than Body Requirements – Related to discomfort while eating or avoidance of food due to symptoms.
Ineffective Breathing Pattern – If the hernia is large, it may press on the diaphragm, causing shortness of breath.
Deficient Knowledge – Related to lack of understanding about lifestyle modifications, dietary changes, and medication adherence.
Risk for Gastrointestinal Bleeding – If chronic irritation leads to esophagitis, ulcers, or Barrett’s esophagus.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Oral Esophageal
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal

What is it:

cold sores or fever blisters commonly found on lips
appear during certain vulnerable periods: stress, weakened immune system
main cause: skin to skin transmission
Risk Factors:

immunosuppressed, infants, young children, elevated stress
exposure to UV light
urban living
poorness
Manifestations

lesions with fluid filled pimples
eventually crust over, dry, and heal
malaise, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and other flu-like complaints
can also be asyptomatic
Complications: nutritional deficits from pain from eating
Diagnosis: exam, Viral culture, PCR testing, Serologic testing for HSV antibodies
Treatment: OTC creams, ibuprofen

What is it

commonly known as a canker sore
circular, reddened lesion that most often presents with a white, gray, or yellowish center
Causes

not fully understood
probably bacterial
Risk Factors: more prevalent in areas with a greater proportion of middle- and high-income communities
Complications

nutritional deficits from pain from eating
Treatment

Topical analgesics (benzocaine, lidocaine)
Anti-inflammatory mouth rinses (steroid, chlorhexidine)
Nutritional supplementation if deficient
Severe cases: oral corticosteroids

What is it

aka THRUSH;
fungal yeast infection
bright white patches or coatings that appear on the tongue and inside of the cheeks
other symptoms: irritation, redness, mouth pain (leads to eating difficulties)
can also be found in throat
occur in clients older than 65 years of age or in individuals who have a weakened immune system
Causes:

trauma to mouth
Risk Factors:

weakened immune system; 65 older
steroids and antibiotic use
stress
improperly fitting dentures
tobacco use
Diagnosis: history, biopsy
Treatment
Nursing Considerations

What is it

Inflammation of the gums caused by plaque buildup along the gumline
Causes
Manifestations

Red, swollen gums, bleeding with brushing or flossing, tenderness, bad breath
gum recession in severe cases
Diagnosis

Clinical examination, assessment of plaque levels, probing for gum pocket depth, and ruling out periodontal disease.
Treatment

Improved oral hygiene, professional dental cleanings
scaling to remove plaque/tartar
smoking cessation, and addressing underlying conditions.

What is it

Chronic inflammatory gum disease causing destruction of soft tissue and bone supporting teeth
Causes

Bacterial plaque accumulation
Poor oral hygiene
Smoking, uncontrolled diabetes
Genetic predisposition
Risk Factors

Smoking, diabetes, poor oral hygiene
Immunosuppression, stress, hormonal changes
Aging, inadequate nutrition
Manifestations

Swollen, red, bleeding gums, gum recession, loose teeth, bad breath
Pain, pus between teeth and gums
Treatment

Scaling, root planing to remove plaque
Antibiotics (topical or systemic)
Surgery (flap surgery, bone grafts) in severe cases
Improved oral hygiene, smoking cessation
Nursing Considerations

Educate on proper oral care, regular dental visits
Assess for risk factors (smoking, diabetes)
Encourage smoking cessation, good nutrition
Monitor for complications like tooth loss, systemic infection

What is it: Malignant growth in oral cavity affecting lips, tongue, gums, cheeks, floor of mouth, or palate
Causes: tobacco use (smoking, chewing), Excessive alcohol consumption, HPV infection, Chronic irritation (ill-fitting dentures, sharp teeth)
Risk Factors

male
chewing/smoking tobacco
alcohol consumption
poor oral hygiene
UV light exposure
HPV
candida infections
immunosuppression
chronic inflammation of mount
Manifestations

Non-healing ulcers, red/white patches
Pain, bleeding, difficulty chewing/swallowing
Lump, thickening, numbness in mouth
Hoarseness, ear pain, weight loss in advanced cases
Diagnosis: direct pharyngoscopy and laryngoscopy, biopsy, scraping of tongue with diagnostic dye
Treatment:

Surgery (tumor removal, possible reconstruction)
Radiation, chemotherapy for advanced cases
Targeted therapy, immunotherapy (specific cases)


tissues in esophagus become precancerous
caused by chronic inflammation from GERD
see GERD for detailed info
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pancreatitis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal
#nursing #medsurg #gastrointestinal


inflammation of the pancreas (from autodigestion of pancreas = digestive enzymes eat the pancreas)
stems from pancreatic duct obstruction (see causes)
acute or chronic
enzymes are key to understanding this disease: protease, lipase, amylase
Pancreas: produces enzymes to digest food; releases insulin and glucagon to regular blood sugar
Acute Pancreatitis - sudden, releases trypsin that causes pancreatic acinar cell death = inflammatory response, usually managed with conservative treatments
Chronic Pancreatitis - ongoing, progressive inflammation, may cause irreversible organ damage from fibrosis and scarring


gall stones and alcohol abuse = most common cause
gall stones - obstruct the pancreatic duct (see Cholecystitis); obstruction causes enzymes to autodigest
alcohol: constant inflammation occludes the duct
diabetes


alcohol abuse
smoking
high-fat diet which leads to gallstone formation
family hx, obesity, DM, cystic fibrosis
old


intense pain in epigastric area or left upper abd (radiates to back, worsens after eating)
abdominal tenderness with guarding
Cullen's Sign - blue grey discoloration sign around belly button (Edward Cullen is blue-grey)
Grey-Turner's Sign - ecchymosis on the patient's flank (you turn to the side to see it)
Fox's Sign - ecchymosis on groin (fox = fuck area / groin)
Infection: fever, chills, tachy, diaphoresis, tachypnea
N/V
Jaundice (see Hepatitis)
Tetany - involuntary muscle contractions, typically caused by low levels of calcium in the blood (hypocalcemia)
dehydration


Kidney Failure
necrotizing pancreatitis - tissue death
Pancreatic pseudocysts (fluid-filled sacs, can rupture and cause bleeding)
SIRS => Organ Failure - greatest risk for death if unresolved within 48 hrs
sepsis
malnutrition
Diabetes T2
Pancreatic Cancer
Recurrent pancreatitis - once you get it, you will most likely get it again


Lipase: elevated, best marker detecting Pancreatitis due to its specificity (lipase is an enzyme that breaks down FATS, secreted by pancreas thru bile salts)
Amylase: elevated, also used but can also be elevated in Bowel Obstruction, Gastric Ulcers (Amylase is an enzyme that breaks down CARBS, secreted by pancreas thru bile salts)
WBC = elevated (see CBC)
Bilirubin = elevated (see LFT)
CMP: low Ca
Glucose (pancreas can't make insulin) = increased
Imaging: US (preferred to detect gallstone), CT, MRCP, ERCP
CRP/ESR = elevated


strict NPO with I/O recording (rest pancreas, reduce enzyme secretion)
IVF for e- correction
NGT nutrition or TPN or PRN decompression
Analgesia
progress to clear liquid, bland diet, low fat diet as tolerated
If blockage is confirmed = ERCP (A scope gets shoved down your throat to check your liver, gallbladder, and pancreas, can also remove gallstones)
Cholecystectomy
Drainage of pancreas if indicated
Enzyme supplements


monitor I/O, pain
monitor for bleeding
monitor for sepsis
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Peritonitis
item.description:
Inflammation of the peritoneum, often due to infection, perforation, or trauma, leading to potential sepsis if untreated.
peritoneum - thin, serous membrane that lines the abdominal cavity and covers most of the abdominal organs
Based on two types:

Spontaneous - no identifiable source, complication of liver failure or AKI/CKD
Secondary


Bowel perforation (Gastric Ulcers, Diverticulitis, appendicitis, Bowel Obstruction)
Peritoneal Dialysis
Abdominal trauma
Surgical complications
Infection spreading from intra-abdominal organs


Abdominal surgery
Perforated peptic ulcer
Diverticulitis
Ruptured appendix
Peritoneal dialysis
Cirrhosis with ascites
Immunosuppression


Severe abdominal pain (worse with movement)
Rigid, board-like abdomen (because of fluid-filled belly)
Rebound tenderness
Fever
Tachycardia
Hypotension
Nausea, vomiting
Decreased bowel sounds
Possible signs of sepsis (altered mental status, respiratory distress)


Clinical assessment (rigid abdomen, rebound tenderness)
CMP - elevated CK, BUN (d/t )
CBC (leukocytosis)
Blood cultures
Abdominal X-ray (check for free air from perforation)
CT scan (source of infection)
Peritoneal fluid analysis (bacteria, WBCs)


IV antibiotics
Fluid resuscitation
NG tube for decompression
Pain management
Surgery for perforation or abscess drainage
Peritoneal lavage if severe infection


NPO, progress accordingly
Avoid gas producing foods: carbonated
Avoid Irritating foods: spicy, high-fat
Once recovered: high protein/high calorie diet to support recovery, high fiber meals


Monitor vital signs for sepsis (fever, tachycardia, hypotension)
Assess for worsening pain or rigidity
Maintain NPO status
Administer IV fluids and antibiotics
Manage NG tube if present
Provide pain relief
Prepare for possible surgical intervention
Educate on infection prevention and post-op care
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: BPH
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


non-cancerous enlargement of prostate gland; Benign Prostate Hyperplasia
common in aging males
Leads to various urinary disorders: Retention, bladder outflow obstruction, urethra constriction


hormonal changes (DHT or dihydrotestosterone, estrogen imbalance)
aging


men over 50
family history
obesity, Metabolic Syndrome, HTN, DM


increased urinary frequency and urgency
weak urine stream
hesitancy
straining
dysuria
nocturia - frequent night time urination
decreased QOL/sef-esteem


urinary retention
UTI, urisepsis
bladder stones
hydronephrosis - kidney damage from backlflow


PSA - prostate specific antigen test
screen for prostate cancer


Alpha blockers: Cardura
Tamsulosin (flomax) - relax smooth muscles in prostate and bladder neck
5-Alpha Reductase Inhibitors
Surgery: prostatectomy for super large prostates over 100g
Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP) = gold standard


Monitor for urinary retention, bladder distention
Educate on medication side effects (dizziness, hypotension)
Encourage timed voiding, fluid management (avoid evening fluids)
Post-TURP: monitor for bleeding, continuous bladder irrigation (CBI)
Teach patients to avoid bladder irritants (caffeine, alcohol)
Reinforce importance of follow-ups for PSA and symptom monitoring


sterile saline fluids to flush clots from the bladder after surgery
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Incontinence
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


involuntary loss of urine
Types:

Stress - caused by weakness of the urethral sphincter or the pelvic floor muscles, involuntarily urine leakage with sneezing, coughing, or physical exertion.
Urge - detrusor muscle overactivity that causes bladder contraction, or; loss of neurologic control or by irritation of the bladder.
Overflow - urine leakage of an overdistended bladder, which is caused by a bladder obstruction that blocks urine excretion or impaired contractility of the detrusor muscle. Bladder obstruction causes of the distended bladder include pelvic organ prolapse, abdominal or pelvic masses, or BPH.
Iatrogenic - caused by medical treatments or interventions like Diuretics, sedatives, surgeries that affect bladder function
Mixed - combination of urge and stress


usually temporary; usually d/t food irritants: alcohol, spicy, sugary, caffeine, carbonated.
Meds: diuretics, BP meds, Doxazosin (cardura), antidepressantsm CCB, ACEi


coughing - stress incontinence
Heart Failure - fluid overload
Neurologic conditions: MS
MSK disorders, mobility issues


stress test: cough
Check for UTI: UA
bladder scan to check post-void residual volume (result of greater than 200mL = overflow incontinence)


Urinary antispasmodics, such as oxybutynin (Ditropan XL)
bladder relaxants, such as Mirabegron (myrbetriq)
Bladder Training - urinating at set time intervals
Pelvic Floor Muscle Training - kegels
Catheters - use judiciously to minimize UTI, can help avoid skin breakdown
Alternative urine collection: condom cath, purewick


falls precautions
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Retention
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


unable to empty bladder


Obstruction: prostate enlargement, urethral structure, renal stone, pelvic mass, stenosis of bladder neck
Underactive Bladder - weak bladder muscles from aging or neuro problems (MS, Parkinsons, stroke, DM, meds)
Medications: anticholinergics, opioids, anesthesia, antihistamines
Postop: anesthesia, prolonged catherization


BPH
cervical cancer
old age - underactive bladder
pregnant - underactive bladder
pelvic organ prolapse
recent surgery
Diabetes
history of pelvic injury


slow urine stream
feeling of full bladder
urge to void
bladder discomfort
distended bladder
200 mL post void residual (PVR) = inadequate emptying
400 mL = urinary retention
Normal PVR: <20mL, 50-100mL for elderly


UTI from urine stasis
Bladder overdistention - loss of bladder tone
Hydronephrosis: kidney damage from backflow
Renal Failure


UA
culture for UTI
Bladder scan: check post void residual scan (PVR)
PSA for BPH
Check for infection: CBC
Check for renal dysfunction/electrolyte imbalance: CMP


treat cause: BPH => 5-Alpha Reductase Inhibitors, Tamsulosin, TURP
urinary strictures: endoscopy urethral dilation
catheterization


Monitor urinary output and bladder distention
Teach catheter care if self-catheterization is required
Educate on medication effects and side effects
Encourage scheduled voiding to prevent overdistention
Assess for UTI symptoms and complications
Provide post-op care if surgical intervention is done
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: UTI
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


broad term indicating infection in bladder, kidneys, ureters/urethra
females more at risk d/t anatomy
Based on Severity

Uncomplicated UTI - or cystitis occurs when the bladder becomes infected with bacteria but there are no comorbidities present.
Complicated UTI - clients who have comorbidities, such as diabetes, who are pregnant, or immunocompromised
Based on Location

Lower UTI: Cystitis - inflammation of the bladder
Lower UTI: Urethritis - inflammation of the urethra
Upper UTI: Pylonephritis - infection of the renal pelvis and kidney
Upper UTI: Ureteritis - less
Based on Source of Infection

Community-Acquired UTI → Occurs in individuals outside healthcare settings
Nosocomial (Hospital-Acquired) UTI → Acquired in a healthcare setting, often associated with urinary catheters (Catheter-Associated UTI or CAUTI)


e.coli - #1 cause; bacteria travels up urethra into the bladder
indwelling catheters
sexual intercourse
pregnancy
poor hygiene


female
frequent pelvic exams
diaphragms
condoms with spermicidal foam
Comorbidities: Diabetes T1, Diabetes T2, immunocompromised


Old fucks: CONFUSION, agitation
Lower UTI: dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency, suprapubic pain, cloudy, foul urine, hematuria
Upper UTI: fever, chills, flank pain (kidney pain), N/V, fatigue, malaise (see Pylonephritis)


Urosepsis - systemic infection that starts in urogenital tract
CKD
Retention


Clean Catch Urinalysis - clean labia three times with sterile wipes, front to back, catch midstream
dipstick urine testing
Urine culture - also midstream
BUN - CMP


antibiotics (Bactrim) - based on culture results
Analgesia
cranberry juice
hydration


encourage hydration
educate proper hygiene
void before/after intercourse
Avoid bladder irritants: caffeine, alcohol, spicy
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: AKI
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


interchangeable term: Acute Kidney Failure (ARF)
sudden onset and usually reversible decrease in kidney function
can progress to CKD and ESRD if not treated
3 Categories
Prerenal - most common, reduced blood flow to kidneys

caused by hypotension, hypovolemia, Heart Failure, Liver failure, renal artery stenosis
Vasodilation: sepsis, anaphylaxis
common cause: Cirrhosis
meds: NSAIDs, ARBs, ACEi, cyclosporine
Intrarenal - direct Kidney Damage (renal cortex and renal medulla)

caused by nephrotoxic agents: contrast dyes, NSAID, aminoglycosides, vancomycin
Acute Tubular Necrosis: deadly, renal tubules become damaged and die, GFT decreases
Glomerulonephritis, lupus nephritis
Rhabdomyolysis
Hemolysis
Postrenal - obstruction of urine flow

Renal Calculi, BPH
tumors, strictures, neurogenic bladder
other ureteral obstructions


sepsis, shock
Nephrotoxic drugs: NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, contrast dyes, ACEi)
kidney disease, diabetes, HTN
major surgery, trauma, burns (fluid loss, rhabdo risk
elderly


Oliguria (<400 mL/day) or Anuria (<100 mL/day) in severe cases
Azotemia (↑ BUN & creatinine) → Causes nausea, confusion, fatigue
Fluid overload → Edema, hypertension, pulmonary congestion
Hyperkalemia → ECG changes (peaked T waves, arrhythmias)
Metabolic acidosis → Kussmaul respirations
Uremic symptoms (pruritus, anorexia, altered mental status)**


e- imbalance
pulmonary edema, Heart Failure
Metabolic acidosis (kussmaul breathing
infection, sepsis
CKD, ESRD


Serum creatinine & BUN → Increased (hallmark of AKI)
GFR → Decreased
Urinalysis → Casts, protein, hematuria (intrarenal causes)
Electrolytes → Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia
Renal ultrasound → Identifies obstruction (postrenal causes)
Fractional Excretion of Sodium (FeNa) → Low in prerenal, high in intrarenal AKI


Prerenal AKI → IV fluids (if hypovolemic), vasopressors if shock
Intrarenal AKI → Avoid nephrotoxins, manage underlying disease
Postrenal AKI → Relieve obstruction (catheter, surgery)
correct e- imbalance or acidosis
Diuretics for fluid overload
Dialysis if severe


#1 priority: e- imbalance, fluid overload, hyperkalemia, cardiac output
adjust nephrotoxic drugs
hydr8


Vancomycin
Tetracycline
Pantoprazole
Omeprazole
Methotrexate
Lithium
Cortisone
Cimetidine
Aspirin 
Allopurinol
Acetaminophen
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: CKD
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


gradual loss of kidney function over time
will lead to ESRD
Differences between AKI:

AKI is usually reversible, CKD is not
CKD is progressive, AKI is sudden (hence the term "acute")

Just note that normal GFR is ≥ 90


Diabetes T2 => most common cause (Diabetes T1 can also be cause but less rare)
Hypertension
Glomerulonephritis
Polycystic Kidney Disease
Obstructions like Renal Calculi, BPH, tumors
Chronic use of NSAIDs


Metabolic Syndrome
smoking
higher risk: Asian, Hispanic, and Black
male 65 and older


Early stage (mild to moderate): no symptoms in earlier stages; can be vague symptoms like fatigue, edema, changes in urination
Fluid overload: edema, jugular vein distention, crackles in lungs, uncontrolled hypertension
anemia (causes fatigue)
e- imbalance
metabolic acidosis
Neuro: lethargy, confusion, hand tremors, sleep disturbances, unusual behavior, and decreased mental sharpness
pruritus (itchy skin)
urine changes: dark, foamy, bloody urine
metallic taste in mouth
poor appetite & unintentional weight loss
Uremic Pericarditis: S3 gallop or pericardial friction rub may be present
uremic frost crystals - crystals form on the skin because your kidneys are so shot that waste builds up in your blood, causing it to sweat out and leave nasty, gritty white crystals all over you


ESRD
Anemia: decreased erythropoietin production leads to lower red blood cell count
Cardiovascular Disease: Increased risk of heart attack, stroke, or heart failure due to CKD's effect on blood vessels constant fluid overload
Metabolic Acidosis
Electrolyte Imbalances: Such as hyperkalemia (high potassium) or hyperphosphatemia
Bone Mineral Disorder: Alterations in calcium and phosphate balance, leading to weakened bones.


GFR
CMP: BUN, Creatinine, e-
UA: + for protein or blood
Urine Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio: A marker for kidney damage.
Ultrasound or CT Scan: To evaluate kidney size, cysts, or obstructions.
Kidney Biopsy: In some cases, to determine the exact cause of CKD.


fluid restrictions
Diuretics
Manage BP: Hypertension meds: ACEi, ARBS
Diet: low protein (to reduce kidney workload = avoid uremia), Na + K restrictions
Manage anemia: ESA and iron supplements
Dialysis: hemo or peritoneal for ESRD
Kidney transplant for ESRD


strict I/O
monitor daily weight
control blood glucose
avoid nephrotoxins: NSAID, smoking, alcohol


Monitor vital signs (BP, HR, temp) before, during, and after dialysis.
Weigh the patient before and after dialysis to assess fluid removal.
Care for the dialysis access site, checking for infection, clotting, or poor flow.
Monitor for electrolyte imbalances and adjust dialysis as needed.
Hold medications like antihypertensives before dialysis.
Educate the patient on treatment, diet, fluid restrictions, and adherence.
Watch for complications like dialysis disequilibrium syndrome, air embolism, or bleeding.
Provide emotional and psychosocial support to manage chronic illness.
Ensure proper anticoagulation and monitor post-dialysis for side effects (hypotension, cramps).
Practice infection control and aseptic technique when accessing the dialysis port.


Excess Fluid Volume - Related to decreased kidney filtration, fluid retention.
Risk for Electrolyte Imbalance - Related to impaired renal function, decreased excretion of electrolytes.
Imbalanced Nutrition: Less Than Body Requirements - Related to decreased appetite, nausea, and vomiting.
Fatigue - Related to anemia, uremia, altered metabolism, decreased kidney function.
Risk for Infection - Related to impaired immune system, dialysis access sites.
Risk for Impaired Skin Integrity - Related to edema, frequent dialysis, uremic pruritus.
Disturbed Body Image - Related to physical changes (e.g., edema, dialysis access devices).
Activity Intolerance - Related to decreased oxygenation, fatigue, and weakness.
Risk for Impaired Gas Exchange - Related to pulmonary edema, fluid overload, respiratory distress.
Chronic Pain - Related to renal disease, uremic pruritus, musculoskeletal pain.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Dialysis
item.description:
A medical procedure that replaces the function of the kidneys when they are no longer able to filter waste, toxins, and excess fluids from the blood.
Function of Dialysis:

remove excess fluid + electrolytes
acid-base balance
remove waste products
restore homeostasis thru osmosis, diffusion, ultra-filtration
Types of Dialysis:
Hemodialysis: Blood is filtered through a machine outside the body to remove waste and excess fluids.
Peritoneal Dialysis: Uses the lining of the abdomen (peritoneum) to filter blood inside the body by infusing a dialysis solution into the abdomen.
Dialysis Access Sites
Hemodialysis: Fistulas, grafts, or central venous catheters (CVC)
Peritoneal Dialysis: Catheter inserted into the abdominal cavity
Dialysis Procedure
Hemodialysis: Blood is removed, cleaned, and returned to the body via a machine over a 3-5 hour period, typically 3 times a week.
Peritoneal Dialysis: Dialysate fluid is infused into the abdomen, where it absorbs waste and excess fluid, and is then drained out, typically performed daily.
Considerations for Fistula

assess patency: presence of bruit, palpable thrill, distal pulses, ciculation
Avoid the fistula sight! do not: measure BP, inject, venipuncture.
Elevate site after fistula creation
Have protamine sulfate ready to reverse heparin.


Renal insufficiency: CKD, AKI, ESRD
Medication or illicit drug toxicity
Persistent hyperkalemia
Pulmonary edema
severe Hypertension
hypervolemia that does not respond to diuretics


Hemodialysis: Infection at the access site, hypotension, muscle cramps, blood clots, anemia
Peritoneal Dialysis: Peritonitis, catheter infection, fluid imbalance, inadequate dialysis


Priority: monitor for K! (RBCs are not affected by Dialysis)
monitor kidney function values: BUN, creatinine
Assess for signs of complications (e.g., infection, fluid overload)
Provide education on dietary restrictions, fluid intake, and medication adherence
Encourage psychological support due to the chronic nature of dialysis treatment


Risk for Infection related to dialysis access site (e.g., fistula, catheter) and immune suppression.
Imbalanced Nutrition: Less than Body Requirements related to dietary restrictions and altered metabolism due to kidney dysfunction.
Fluid Volume Excess related to impaired renal function and fluid retention.
Fatigue related to dialysis procedure and chronic kidney disease.
Risk for Electrolyte Imbalance related to dialysis treatment, particularly changes in potassium, calcium, and sodium levels.


Fluid restriction
Limit Na
Limit K (bananas, beans, potatoes, oranges, tomatoes, spinach, avocados)
High protein to prevent muscle loss (dialysis removes protein in blood but for CKD patients that are not undergoing dialysis, limiting protein may be indicate to prevent Uremia)
Uremia - buildup of waste products in the blood due to kidney failure
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: ESRD
item.description:
End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD)


Final stage of CKD where kidneys can no longer maintain fluid, electrolyte, and waste balance
GFR < 15 mL/min, requiring dialysis or kidney transplant for survival
Leads to multisystem complications due to accumulation of toxins, fluid overload, and hormonal imbalances


Diabetes mellitus (Diabetic nephropathy) → Leading cause
Hypertension → Chronic high BP damages glomeruli
Polycystic Kidney Disease
Glomerulonephritis (chronic inflammation damaging nephrons)
Autoimmune diseases (Lupus, IgA nephropathy)
Obstructive uropathy (chronic kidney stones, BPH, reflux nephropathy)


Uncontrolled diabetes & hypertension
Family history of kidney disease
Obesity, smoking, high-sodium diet
Nephrotoxic medications (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides)
African American, Hispanic, Native American ethnicity (higher prevalence of diabetes & HTN)


Fluid overload → Edema, pulmonary congestion, hypertension
Uremia (toxin buildup) → Fatigue, confusion, pruritus, nausea, metallic taste
Electrolyte imbalances → Hyperkalemia (dysrhythmias), metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia
Anemia → Pallor, weakness (decreased erythropoietin production)
Bone disease (renal osteodystrophy) → Bone pain, fractures (due to calcium/phosphorus imbalance)
Cardiovascular complications → Heart failure, pericarditis, arrhythmias


Cardiovascular disease (leading cause of death in ESRD patients)
Hyperkalemia-induced cardiac arrest
Pulmonary edema from fluid overload
Infections (weakened immune system, dialysis access site infections)
Uremic encephalopathy (neurological dysfunction from toxin buildup)
Malnutrition (protein-energy wasting common in dialysis patients)


Serum creatinine & BUN → Significantly elevated, see CMP
GFR < 15 mL/min → Diagnostic of ESRD
Electrolytes (↑K+, ↓Ca2+, ↑Phosphate, metabolic acidosis)
Hemoglobin & hematocrit (↓ due to erythropoietin deficiency)
Renal ultrasound → Small, atrophied kidneys (except in PKD)


Dialysis (Hemodialysis or Peritoneal Dialysis)
Kidney transplant (preferred long-term solution)
Fluid & dietary restrictions (low sodium, potassium, phosphorus, and protein moderation)
Erythropoietin-stimulating agents (epoetin alfa) for anemia
Phosphate binders (calcium acetate, sevelamer) to prevent bone disease
Vitamin D & calcium supplements to manage hypocalcemia
Blood pressure & glucose control to slow progression in early CKD


Monitor fluid status (daily weights, edema, lung sounds, BP)
Assess for dialysis complications (hypotension, infection, disequilibrium syndrome)
Monitor potassium levels & cardiac rhythm (risk of hyperkalemia-induced arrhythmias)
Educate on dietary restrictions (low sodium, potassium, phosphorus, and controlled protein intake)
Administer medications safely (adjust dosages for renal impairment, avoid nephrotoxic drugs)
Assess for uremic symptoms (pruritus, confusion, nausea)
Encourage adherence to treatment plan (dialysis schedule, medications, diet)

item.title: Glomerulonephritis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


inflammation of the glomeruli, impairs kidney function => more waste in blood steam, e- imbalance, loss of blood RBC and protein
can be acute or chronic
results in proteinuria, azotemia, hematuria
proteinuria => elevated cholesterol, HTN, edema
severity is classified based on proteinuria of greater than 3.5g/day and edema
Azotemia - elevated N2 waste products such as urea and creatinine
Acute - primary renal cause or by an illness that impairs renal function
Chronic - progressive, leads to ESRD


streptococcal infection - most common; usually after a strep throat (Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus)
Endocarditis - also linked to gn (watch out for cardiac valve replacement)
Autoimmune diseases (Lupus, IgA nephropathy, Goodpasture’s syndrome)
Vasculitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis, polyarteritis nodosa)
Diabetes mellitus (Diabetic nephropathy leading to glomerular damage)
Bacterial endocarditis, viral infections (Hepatitis B, C, HIV)


see causes
family history of kidney disease
Drug toxicity: NSAID, abx, illegal drugs


periorbital edema: hallmark symptom
decreased eGFR (normal is greater than 60/ml/min)
dark and frothy urine
decreased UOP
elevated BP - from fluid overload and RAAS activation
infection: fever, malaise, weakness
abdominal discomfort


CKD that can lead to ESRD
Acute Kidney Injury
Nephrotic Syndrome - severe protein loss, high cholesterol, edema
Pulmonary edema, Heart Failure, due to fluid overload
Hypertensive crisis from uncontrolled BP


CMP - check e-, elevated K, BUN, creatinine
GFR: down
UA: RBC, WBC, protein, casts => indicates glomerular damage
Kidney Biopsy
CXR: pulmonary edema
US


goal: manage cause, avoid CKD and ESRD
Corticosteroids: prednisone for anti-inflammation and immune suppression
Abx if caused by stre[
Diuretics: manage edema
ACEi/ARBs - control BP, reduce proteinuria
Dialysis: for AKI or ESRD
Diet restriction: low Na, K, protein, fluid restriction


#1 Priority: manage BP as this can lead to further kidney damage
Second level priority: decreased UOP
salt restriction
more severe: Na, K, protein restriction to slow progression
Lifestyle: smoking, DM, HTN

item.title: Pylonephritis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


kidney infection
Ascending infection: develops from lower UTI where bacteria travels from urethra=>bladder=>ureters=>kidney
2 Types:

Acute - abrupt swelling
Chronic - aka reflux nephropathy, is much rarer than the acute condition and is diagnosed when repeated bouts of acute pyelonephritis occur usually in clients with urinary obstructions


e.coli
other bacteria (klebsiella, etc)
obstruction: BPH, stones, strictures (narrowing of urinary tract)
Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) (backward urine flow from bladder to kidneys)
prolonged catheterization


females
renal stones
kidney or bladder disorders
immunosuppression
enlarged prostate
urinary catheters
Diabetes => can lead to emphysematous pyelonephritis, which is a necrotizing infection that destroys the kidney tissues


fever over 102F
pain in side, back, or groin
dysuria
cloudy or bloody urine
fishy odor urine
General infection sx: chills, N/V, fatigue
mental confusion


Emphysematous Pyelonephritis
Renal Abscesses => pus in kidney
Thrombosis in Renal Vein
Acute Renal Failure
Hypertension d/t kidney damage


UA with culture
CBC
Renal US
DMSA - dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) test would show any scarring in the urinary tract due to pyelonephritis using a radioactive material injected into the arm then images are taken during the material’s passage through the kidneys.


abx, levofloxacin, ampicillin


educate: wipe from front to back
Assess CVA tenderness
monitor BUN, creatinine, UOP

item.title: Renal Calculi
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


kidney stones, nephrolithiasis, or urolithiasis
caused by accumulation of minerals and salts that lodge in the kidney or urinary tract = pain, hematuria


Dehydration: most common
Calcium Oxalate (most common) in urine
Calcium Phosphate
uric acid (look out for gout)
struvite
cystine stones: genetic
Hyperparathyroidism


diet: high sodium, high oxalate( spinach, nuts, chocolate), high purine (red meat, alcohol, shellfishh)
environmental: extreme heat and sun exposure = e- imbalance
lifestyle
genetic: family hx
gout (uric aid stone)
age: 43 and older
male: twice as likely
obesity
frequent UTI
Diabetes T2
CKD
HTN


severe flank pain with acute oset
N/V
infection: fever, malaise, etc
If presents with Pylonephritis, surgery may be required


Urinary Obstruction => hydronephrosis (kidney swelling) => HIGH PRIORITY
Pylonephritis, sepsis
AKI


UA: check RBC, WBC, crystals
Non-contrast CT = gold standard
Renal US: useful for pregnant patients, children
KUB X-ray (Kidney, Ureter, Bladder)


observation: if stones are small (<5mm)
Tamsulosin (alpha blockers): relax ureter muscles for easier stone passage
CCB: for vasodilation (do not use if hypotensive)
Analgesia
Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) → Breaks stones using sound waves
Ureteroscopy with stone removal → For larger or impacted stones
Percutaneous nephrolithotomy → For large or complex stones


risk for obstruction( dec UOP, pain, hematuria)
risk for infection
strain urine to collect stone

item.title: Anemia
item.description:
#cbc

abnormally low RBC, Hgb concentration, or HCT
indicator of underlying disease or disorder
results in diminished o2 carrying capacity and delivery to tissues and organs


Little to no manifestations in mild cases
Pallor
Fatigue, somnolence, and headache
Irritability
Numbness and tingling of extremities (paresthesia)
Dyspnea on exertion
Sensitivity to cold
Pain and hypoxia with sickle-cell crisis
SOB, tachy, dizziness
nail deformities when chronic


goal of treatment is to restore and maintain adequate tissue oxygenation
Iron Supplements: oral, IV for severe cases
Erythropoietin: epoetin alfa - ematopoietic growth factor used to increase production of RBCs
monitor for increased BP, monitor CBC, monitor for cardiac event
B12 supplements - to convert folic acid
administer parenterally if lack of intrinsic factors/stomach malabsorption
Folic Acid Supplements
Blood Transfusions - for severe only due to risk of infections


Prevention:
pregnant/menstruating = ensure more iron foods, iron supplements
iron-deficient and have elevated cholesterol levels => eat more iron-rich foods that are not red or organ meats into their diets
eat more folate (spinach, lentils, bananas) and folic acid fortified grains and juices


CBC #cbc
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): Size of red blood cells
Normocytic: Normal size
Microcytic: Small cells
Macrocytic: Large cells
Mean corpuscular Hgb (MCH): Determines the amount of Hgb per RBC
Mean corpuscular Hgb concentration (MCHC): Indicates percentage of Hgb present relative to the size of the cell
Iron Studies
Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) - an indirect measurement of all proteins that bind with iron and transports it for storage
Sickle cell
Schilling Test - measure B12 absorption for G6PD


blood loss
Inadequate RBC production (hypoproliferative)
Increased RBC destruction (hemolytic)
Deficiency of necessary components (folic acid, iron, erythropoietin, vitamin B12)


acute or chronic blood loss (trauma, menorrhagia, GI, chemical or radiation exposure)
rapid metabolic activity: pregnancy, adolescence, infection
Increased hemolysis: Sickle Cell, Impaired Glycolysis: G6PD deficiency anemia, Immune Disorders,
Trauma to RBCs: mechanical heart valve, cardiopulmonary bypass
Diet or malabsorption: iron, folic acid
Pernicious Anemia - deficiency of intrinsic factor produced by gastric mucosa, which is necessary for absorption of vitamin B12
Pica - persistent eating of substances not normally considered food (nonnutritive substances), such as soil or chalk
Bone Marrow Suppression - exposure to radiation or chemicals
Aplastic anemia - results in fewer RBCs as well as decreased platelets and WBC
Age - Older adult clients are at risk for nutrition-deficient anemias; can be misdiagnosed as depression
Complications

heart failure due to increased heart demand
