item.title: DVT
item.description:
type of blood clot that forms in large veins of extremities or pelvis
usually occurs in lower extremities
3rd most common cause of death among cardiovascular disorders
DVT will go unnoticed but can dislodge and result in a pulmonary embolus, a life-threatening event
Types:
provoked: from an acquired cause (obesity, cancer, immobility)
unprovoked: from an endogenous cause such as recurrence
Proximal: above the knee, and this type is more likely to cause complications leading to PE
Distal: below the knee (most common)


pain, redness, swelling, warmth at affected extremity**
edema


no longer recommended: DVT filters on inferior vena cava
Prophylaxis: SCD, Xa inhibitors (Eliquis, newer class)


ambulate early
anticoags
administer Lovenox - low molecular weight heparin injection
conduct "wells criteria test" - establish DVT risk


venous doppler - detects bloow flow
venography - invasive procedure involving contrast dye and xray
d-dimer
MRI


caused by damage to the wall of a blood vessel
turbulence to blood flow, such as with atrial fibrillation, a heart arrhythmia
hypercoagulability, meaning the blood is increasingly coagulating or clotting
decreased blood flow due to immobility, surgery, catheter
dehydration due to increased blood viscosity
genetics - factor V Leiden (FVL) mutation
CHF, COPD
hospital stay


immobility: bedrest, airplane right, anesthesia
hormonal: pregnant, contraceptive therapy or hormone replacement therapy with estrogen
smoking
family hx, previous hx
old age
tumors
sepsis
chronic health conditions: HTN, DM
Usual comorbidities: cellulitis, thrombophlebitis, eczema, vasculitis, cancer, CHF, IBS
obesity: pressure on the lower extremities
SSC


DVT can dislodge and travel = becomes a PE


Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) - profoundly serious health condition
clotting and anticlotting mechanisms occur at the same time.
hypovolemic shock
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hematological everything else
item.description:
#hematologic #anemia #nursing #medsurg #bloodclot #anticoagulant #stroke
#hematologic #anemia #nursing #medsurg

#bloodclot
What is it

Blood clots are made up of platelets and fibrin and are a gel-like consistency
thrombus - when blocks vein or artery
arterial thrombosis - occurs in artery
venous
Embolus/embolism - if it moves throughout the body; can cause serious harm
Subtypes

Pulmonary Embolism
Myocardial Infarction (MI)
Ischemic Stroke - occurs in artery to the brain caused by plaque (fatty deposits)
Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
Clinical Presentation

chest pain that worsens with deep breathing
tachycardia, SOB, lightheadedness, hemoptysis
MI: chest pain radiating left arm, SOB, diaphoresis
Stroke: facial weakness, difficulty speaking, visual deficit, L/R sided weakness, seizures Treatment
Thrombolytics - class of meds that dissolve clots
Tissue Plasminogen Activator - give within 3 hours for stroke, do not use with hemorrhagic stroke, verify with CT
Thrombectomy - specialized instruments to surgically remove a blood clot
Prevention:
Coumadin/Warfarin - avoid diet changes, monitor INR, high K diet contradicts this medication
Factor Xa Inhibitors - Eliquis, monitoring not required, oral
Lovenox/Enoxaparin
Heparin - Hold heparin if the platelet count is less than 100,000/mm, monitor aPTT
Plavix/Clopidogrel
Antiplatelets - ensures platelets do not stick together
most common: aspirin, clopidogrel (Plavix), usually prescribed with ACS Nursing Interventions
ambulate
diet
note aging adults challenges
be on alert with anticoagulants #anticoagulant
higher risk for bleeding
Warfarin - needs INR, diet restrictions
Causes/Risk Factors

injury or damage to vein
surgery exacerbated by bed rest
hormonal: oral contraceptives, pregnancy, hormone replacement, estrogen (menopause, prostate cancer)
child birth after first 3 months
smoking
cancers: lungs, brain, pancreas, uterus, ovaries, blood cancers, chemotherapy
family history
Atrial Fibrillation
Infection
mechanical heart valves
SSC - systemic sclerosis, aka "scleroderma": also provides increased risk for clots
Diagnosis

D-dimer test: blood test, high = clot. can also be present during pregnancy or postop
small fragment of protein is detected from blood clot
not definitive, more testing needed if positive
CT, US, MRA (magnetic resonance angiography)
MRA = more specific to blood vessels
V/Q scan - ventilation/perfusion test aided by radioactive and imaging techniques
Systemic Effects

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) - profoundly serious health condition
clotting and anticlotting mechanisms occur at the same time

What is it

Hemorrhage: Loss of blood from damaged vessels, inside or outside the body.
Severity impacts treatment and prognosis.
Blood loss classess:
Class I - 0-15%
Class II - 15-30% (shock symptoms apparent)
Class III - 30-40% (delayed cap refill, SBP<90, tachy)
Class IV - 40% or more, no UOP, peripheral pulses absent, shock
Types of Hemorrhages:

Intracranial - brain bleeds
Pulmonary - hemothorax; caused by trauma, cancer, or clotting
Stroke - hemorrhagic; vessels rupture and blood leaks into brain
Clinical Presentation

Symptoms vary: nausea, dizziness, cool skin, shortness of breath, weakness, tachycardia, confusion.
Internal bleeding signs: hemoptysis, hematemesis, clammy skin, abdominal rigidity, altered consciousness.
intracranial hemorrhage: #stroke
headaches, slurred speech or difficulty speaking, facial numbness, upper and lower extremity weakness or numbness, decreased level of consciousness, seizures, or difficulty with ambulating
Treatment

IV fluids, blood transfusion, oxygen therapy, warming blankets, emotional support.
Type and cross-match for blood products.
Physical and occupational therapy for rehabilitation.
Nursing Interventions

Goal: stop the bleed
Assess and identify bleeding source, apply pressure, ensure IV access, administer fluids.
Monitor vital signs, oxygen saturation, and mental status.
Educate on gradual activity increase and rest.
MAP > 65 mm Hg indicates adequate cardiac perfusion.
MAP = (DBP×2) + SBP /3
Diagnostic Tools

CBC, platelet count, PT, PTT.
CT scans, x-rays, ultrasounds
endoscopy for suspected GI bleeds.
Causes

Traumatic injuries, cancer, clotting disorders, elevated BP leading to ruptured aneurysm.
Risk Factors

Trauma, accidents, cancer
blood clotting disorders: hemophillia (genetic mutation)
poor people = higher risk
postpartum hemorrhage = atony (flaccid fetus due to significant blood loss during childbirth or postpartum period)
Systemic Effects

Hypovolemic shock: decreased cardiac output, circulatory insufficiency, hypoxemia.
Cognitive impairments, fatigue, depression, anxiety, PTSD.
Orthostatic hypotension increases fall risk.

item.title: Sickle Cell Anemia
item.description:
affects the shape of the red blood cells in the body by causing hemoglobin to be sticky
cause tissues in the body to become hypoxic, leading to many complications
sickle-shaped RBCs flowing through the blood vessels of the client’s abdomen, chest, and joints cause severe pain, which can last for hours or days
Vaso-Occlusive Crisis (VOC) - a painful complication of sickle cell anemia that occurs when blood vessels are blocked by sickle-shaped red blood cells
Symptoms: severe pain, acute chest syndrome (reduced lung perfusion = DEADLY), dactilytis (inflammation of finger, toes), priapism


severe pain - affects ADLs, damage to joints
can cause anxiety, depression, stress, sleep disorder, poor coping
fatigue caused by anemia (sickle cells die within 10-20 days, normal life span is 120 days)
swelling of hands and feet
visual deficits (sickle cells block vessels in eyes)
anemia symptoms
Acute Chest Syndrome - emergency


pain management
IV fluids for hydration
blood transfusion
Hydroxyurea - reactivates production of fetal hemoglobin
prevention:
drink 8 glasses water daily to prevent dehydration (dehydration = crisis)
avoid extreme temp changes
avoid high altitudes affecting O2 intake


lookout for iron overload arising from frequent blood transfusions
iron deposits in organs = organ damage
needs iron chelation therapy
encourage support group


newborn screening - serum test
Hemoglobin electrophoresis to identify the type of hemoglobin.
Complete blood count (CBC) showing anemia and high reticulocyte count.
Peripheral blood smear showing sickled cells.


both parents must be carriers of the sickle cell trait for the child to be affected
if only one parent is carrier, child will be carrier only


genetics


stroke
blindness
blood clots during pregnancy and hypertension
acute chest syndrome - most serious
blood flow can be blocked to the lungs, causing breathing difficulty, fever, and severe chest pain
emergency!
Damage to organs, pulmonary hypertension, leg ulcerations due to poor circulation, blindness, priapism, DVT, and gallstones are all diseases or disorders that can occur in clients who have sickle cell anemia.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Thrombocytopenia
item.description:
Low platelet count (<150,000 platelets/mm³) leading to increased bleeding risk
Mild (100,000–150,000/mm³): Usually asymptomatic
Moderate (50,000–100,000/mm³): Risk of prolonged bleeding
Severe (<50,000/mm³): High risk for spontaneous bleeding
Critical (<20,000/mm³): Risk of life-threatening hemorrhage


Decreased platelet production
Bone marrow disorders (leukemia, aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome)
Chemotherapy, radiation therapy
Viral infections (HIV, hepatitis, Epstein-Barr virus)
Nutritional deficiencies (vitamin B12, folate)
DMARDs
Increased platelet destruction
Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)
Autoimmune diseases (lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
Increased platelet sequestration - Splenomegaly (due to liver disease, lymphoma)


Cancer treatments (chemotherapy, radiation)
Autoimmune disorders
Chronic infections (HIV, H. pylori)
Liver disease (cirrhosis, portal hypertension)
Use of blood-thinning medications (heparin, warfarin)
Genetic disorders (Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, Fanconi anemia)


Easy bruising (ecchymosis)
Petechiae (tiny red or purple spots on skin)
Prolonged bleeding from minor cuts
Gum or nosebleeds (epistaxis)
Heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia)
Blood in urine (hematuria) or stool (melena)
Severe cases: Intracranial hemorrhage, GI bleeding


Uncontrolled bleeding (internal or external)
Intracranial hemorrhage (life-threatening)
Severe anemia due to blood loss
Shock if bleeding is extensive


Complete Blood Count (CBC): Low platelet count
Peripheral blood smear (assess platelet shape and function)
Bone marrow biopsy (if bone marrow failure suspected)
Coags (PT, PTT, INR) (to rule out clotting disorders)
HIT antibody test (if heparin-induced thrombocytopenia suspected)


Treat underlying cause (infection, bone marrow suppression, autoimmune disease)
Platelet transfusions (for severe thrombocytopenia or active bleeding)
Corticosteroids or IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) (for immune-related thrombocytopenia)
Discontinuation of causative drugs (e.g., heparin in HIT)
Plasmapheresis (for TTP)
Splenectomy (if refractory ITP)
Avoid NSAIDs, aspirin, and anticoagulants


Monitor platelet count trends and bleeding symptoms
Implement bleeding precautions:
Use soft toothbrush, avoid flossing
Avoid IM injections and invasive procedures
Use electric razor instead of a blade
Prevent falls and injuries
Apply prolonged pressure to any bleeding sites
Monitor for signs of internal bleeding (hypotension, tachycardia, pallor, dizziness)
Educate patient on bleeding risk and safety measures


Risk for bleeding related to low platelet count
Impaired oral mucous membrane related to gum bleeding
Risk for injury related to fall risk and potential bleeding
Deficient knowledge related to thrombocytopenia management

item.title: Vitamin Deficiency Anemia (pernicious)
item.description:
Results from fewer healthy RBCs due to the body’s low vitamin B12 and folate levels
B12 is essential for DNA synthesis in the production of RBCs, leading to immature, large cells
Absorption problem (lack of intrinsic factor) or diet issue


Autoimmune: Pernicious Anemia (terminal ileum cannot absorb B12)
Malabsorption: lack of intrinsic factor
Disease: celiac or Crohn’s
Nutritional deficits: vegan diet


Antiseizure meds: reduces B12 absorption
Gastric surgery
Alcohol consumption
DM meds
PPI
Contraceptives
Old age
Celiac/Crohn’s
Sjogren’s Syndrome: dry mucous membranes, including dry mouth and eyes


Little to no manifestations in mild cases
Pallor
Fatigue, somnolence, and headache
Irritability
Numbness and tingling of extremities (paresthesia)
Dyspnea on exertion
Sensitivity to cold
Pain and hypoxia with sickle-cell crisis
SOB, tachy, dizziness
nail deformities when chronic


Newborns: developmental delay, spine/brain defects
Dementia
Mood changes, psych issues
Neuropathy, ataxia


B12: injection, nasal spray, oral
Diet changes: include red meat, chicken, fish, milk


Note safety issues due to peripheral neuropathy; ADLs may be impaired
Visual problems increase the risk of falls


CBC with peripheral smear
B12 and folate serum

item.title: HIV-AIDS
item.description:
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) => a retrovirus that is transmitted through blood and body fluids (semen, vaginal secretions)
also found in feces, urine, tears, saliva, cerebrospinal fluid, cervical cells, lymph nodes, corneal tissue, and brain tissue
attacks CD4+ T cells, weakening the immune system
CD4

protein found on the surface of certain immune cells, known as helper T cells
crucial in recognizing and responding to infections
CD4 range: 500-1,500 cells/mm3 (average adult, lower for younger or elderly)

Stage 1 - Acute HIV Infection

Occurs 2-4 weeks after exposure
Rapid viral replication and spread
Symptoms: Flu-like symptoms (fever, sore throat, rash, swollen lymph nodes, headache)
Highly infectious phase
CD4+ T-Lymphocyte Count: 500 cells/mm3 or more
Stage 2 - Chronic HIV, latent

Virus continues to replicate at low levels
Can last for several years (longer with ART)
Symptoms: Few or no symptoms
Gradual decline in CD4+ T-cell count
CD4+ T-Lymphocyte Count: 200 to 499 cells/mm3
Stage 3 - AIDS

Final stage, severe immune system damage
Vulnerable to opportunistic infections and cancers
Symptoms: Severe immunosuppression, opportunistic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, pneumonia, candidiasis), cancers (Kaposi’s sarcoma, lymphoma)
CD4+ count below 200 cells/mm³ (less than 14% of lymphocytes)


Unprotected seggs (vaginal, anal, oral)
Multiple seggs partners
Occupational exposure (health care workers)
Perinatal exposure
Blood transfusions (not a significant source of infection in the U.S.)
IV drug use with a contaminated needle


Chills
Rash
Anorexia, nausea, weight loss
Weakness and fatigue
Headache and sore throat
Night sweats


Opportunistic infections
cancers (Kaposi’s sarcoma, lymphoma)
neurological issues (HIV-associated dementia)
wasting syndrome - significant unintentional weight loss, muscle wasting, and fatigue
organ failure.


CBC and differential: Abnormal (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia)
Platelet count: Decreased less than 150,000/mm3
HIV antibody screening test (ELISA, Western blot, IFA, home test kit)
Test viral load before beginning treatment
HIV Drug resistant testing - guides medication therapy
Brain or lung MRI/CT


antiretroviral therapy (ART) - suppress viral replication and restore immune function


All women who are pregnant should be screened for HIV
DO NOT administer live virus vaccines (especially for CD4+ count below 200 cells/mm³ due to the risk of uncontrolled viral replication)
positive Western blot or IFA test => client has been exposed to and has the AIDS virus in their body BUT does not mean the client has clinical AIDS.
Promote medication adherence
monitor for side effects of ART
educate on transmission prevention
provide emotional support
encourage routine screening
encourage high protein diet - at least six small feedings with high protein value
manage symptoms of opportunistic infections: TB, Pneumonia, septicemia, kaposis sarcoma, lymphoma
report indications of infection immediately to the provider
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Lupus
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Meningitis
item.description:
inflammation of the meninges (protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord)
viral or bacterial (sometimes parasitic => rare)
causes disruption in neuro functions d/t inflammation
Bacterial - medical emergency due to rapid progression & high mortality
Viral - resolves on its own, less serious


Viral: HSV, enteroviruses (common in warm places/tropical), HIV, measles, mumps, West Nile virus
Bacterial: Hib, Listeria monocytogenes (common in elderly/newborns), Strep pneumoniae, Enteroviruses (common among 5 below)
Funga (rare)
Parasitic (rare)


Immunocompromised - HIV, very old, very young
living in group setting
travel
Direct Bacterial entry - head trauma, skull fractures, neurosurgery
unvaccinated
Recent Surgery: spine, lack of spleen, CSF leak


Classic Triad: Fever, Stiff Neck (nuchal rigidity), altered mental status
Severe headache
Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
Nausea and vomiting
Seizures (in severe cases)
Confusion, lethargy, irritability
Petechial rash (meningococcal meningitis)
Positive Brudzinski’s sign (neck flexion causes knee flexion)
Positive Kernig’s sign (pain with knee extension when hip is flexed)


Sepsis (meningococcemia, life-threatening)
Seizures and epilepsy
Hearing loss (common long-term effect)
Hydrocephalus (CSF buildup in brain)
Cognitive impairments, learning disabilities
Brain damage, coma, or death (if untreated or severe cases)


lumbar puncture (LP): Bacterial => cloudy CSF, ↑ protein, ↓ glucose (bacteria is eating the glucose)
Blood cultures** (to identify bacterial source)
CT/MRI scan (rule out brain abscess, increased ICP before LP)
Nasal/throat swabs (detect viral or bacterial organisms)


Viral; supportive care, Acyclovir (if HSV)
Bacterial: ABX (Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime + vancomycin,)
Reduce brain swell: dexamethasone
Seizure Precautions
ICP management => manage BP, avoid straining, elevate HOB
Prevention: vaccination


Monitor neurological status (LOC, pupil response, vital signs)
Implement droplet precautions for bacterial meningitis (until 24 hrs after antibiotics)
Elevate HOB 30 degrees (reduce ICP)
Reduce environmental stimuli (quiet, dim lights for photophobia)
Monitor for signs of increased ICP (worsening headache, vomiting, bradycardia, hypertension)
Administer pain relievers, fever reducers (acetaminophen)
Encourage vaccination (Hib, pneumococcal, meningococcal vaccines prevent bacterial forms)
Contraindications for LP: increased ICP, Thrombocytopenia, suspected spinal epidural abscess


maintain or normalize BP
manage fever & pain
prevent seizures
maintain or improve neuro status
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Osteoarthritis
item.description:
Degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and underlying bone
Most common form of arthritis, affecting weight-bearing joints (knees, hips, spine, hands)
Progressive (irreversible) and non-inflammatory, leading to pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility
osteo = bone
Bone Spurs - occurs because of changes in bone; small pieces of bone that form at joints with arthritis leading to further breakdown of joints and cartilage
Comparison vs Rheumatoid Arthritis
Osteoarthritis - caused by joint mechanical stress, affects big joints, more common
Rheumatoid - autoimmune, inflammatory, affects all joints, less common


Cartilage deterioration due to mechanical stress and aging
Chronic joint overuse (e.g., repetitive movements, high-impact activities)
Joint misalignment or instability
Obesity-related increased joint load
Previous joint injuries or surgeries


Aging (most common in adults over 50)
Obesity (increased stress on weight-bearing joints)
Joint injuries or trauma
Repetitive stress from occupation or sports
Genetic predisposition
Muscle weakness and poor joint support


joint pain (worsens with activity, relieved by rest)
Morning stiffness (lasting <30 minutes)
Crepitus (grating sound) with movement
Decreased range of motion and flexibility
Joint swelling (mild, non-inflammatory)
Bony enlargements (Heberden’s nodes on distal fingers, Bouchard’s nodes on proximal fingers)


Chronic pain and disability
Joint deformity and stiffness
Decreased mobility leading to muscle atrophy
Increased risk of falls due to instability
Depression and reduced quality of life


clinical assessment
XR, MRI
erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) to show inflammation (ref: 0-15 for male 0-20, female => higher if older)
synovial fluid analysis - to rule out inflammatory arthritis


no permanent treatment; supportive unless severe
Non-pharmacologic: weight loss (reduce joint stress), PT & exercise (improve strength), assistive device & better shoes (comfort), hot/cold therapy (pain relief)
Pharmacologic: acetaminophen, NSAIDs, capsaicin, lidocaine, hyaluronic acid injection (lubricates joints), steroid shots
Surgical (severe): joint replacement (aka arthroplasty)


Encourage regular exercise (low-impact like swimming, walking)
Teach joint protection techniques (assistive devices, ergonomic adjustments)
Promote weight management (reduces joint strain)
Administer and monitor pain medications (watch for NSAID-related GI side effects)
Encourage warm showers or heat therapy to relieve stiffness
Monitor for complications like decreased mobility and fall risk


Chronic pain related to joint degeneration
Impaired physical mobility due to joint stiffness and pain
Self-care deficit related to limited joint function
Activity intolerance related to fatigue and discomfort
Risk for falls due to joint instability and muscle weakness

item.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis
item.description:
Chronic autoimmune disease causing systemic inflammation and progressive joint destruction
Patho: synovium is inflamed, immune system attacks tissue surrounding joint, causing damage (including eyes, mouth, heart, lungs)
Symmetrical polyarthritis, primarily affecting small joints (hands, wrists, feet)
Leads to pain, swelling, stiffness, and deformities
Can also affect organs (heart, lungs, eyes, skin)


Autoimmune response triggering synovial inflammation
Genetic predisposition (HLA-DR4 and HLA-DR1 genes)
Environmental triggers (e.g., smoking, infections)


Female sex (3:1 female-to-male ratio)
Ages 30-50 (peak onset)
Family history of RA
Smoking (strongest modifiable risk factor)
Obesity (linked to disease severity)
Infections (may trigger immune response)


Symmetric joint pain and stiffness (lasting >1 hour in the morning)
Swollen, warm, and tender joints
Most commonly affects: fingers, wrists, elbows, knees, ankles
Joint deformities over time (swan neck, boutonnière, ulnar deviation)
Fatigue, low-grade fever, weight loss
AFFECTS THE WHOLE BODY

Mouth - gum disease, dry, tooth decay
Limbs - deformities, swelling, locking, weakening, ruptured tendons, bunions
Skin: rash, ulcers, Rheumatoid nodules (subcutaneous lumps), neuropathy
Lungs: COPD, (interstitial fibrosis, pleuritis)
Kidneys: impaired function d/t buildup of proteins (amyloidosis)
Eye inflammation (scleritis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca)


Joint deformities and disability
Osteoporosis (due to chronic inflammation and steroid use)
Cardiovascular disease (increased risk of heart attack/stroke)
Lung disease (fibrosis, pleural effusions)
Anemia of chronic disease
Infections (due to immunosuppressive therapy)


clinical assessment
Rheumatoid factor (RF) (positive in 70-80% of cases)
Anti-CCP antibodies (more specific for RA)
Elevated ESR & CRP (indicate inflammation)
XR: shows joint erosion, osteopenia, narrowing of joint space
MRI/US: early synovitis detection
Culture from Synovial Fluid - r/o bacteria (yes, it can be aspirated)

no cure; only management of symptoms
Pharmacologic:

DMARDs (disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) – first-line, Methotrexate (MTX) (gold standard)
Biologic DMARDs (if unresponsive to traditional DMARDs) - TNF inhibitors
NSAIDs and corticosteroids (for symptom relief, but not disease progression)
Non-Pharmacologic:

PT - joint mobility, increase muscle strength
assistive devices (splints, braces)
rest during flare-ups, activity during remission


Monitor for side effects of DMARDs (e.g., liver toxicity, bone marrow suppression, Thrombocytopenia - platelet under 100k)
Educate on medication adherence (early treatment prevents joint damage)
Encourage joint protection techniques (avoid prolonged gripping, use adaptive tools)
Promote balanced rest and exercise
Apply warm/cold therapy (warm packs for stiffness, cold packs for inflammation)
Monitor for extra-articular complications (lung, heart, skin issues)
Encourage smoking cessation (reduces disease progression)
Regularly test for TB (DMARDs)
DMARDs - MTX: causes immunosuppression, not for pregnant, bleeding risk, photosensitivity, sun exposure sensitivity


Chronic pain related to joint inflammation
Impaired physical mobility due to joint stiffness and deformities
Self-care deficit related to decreased hand function
Risk for falls due to joint instability
Fatigue related to systemic inflammation
Risk for infection due to immunosuppressive therapy
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: End of Life
item.description:
Stages:

Early Stage: Loss of mobility, reduced desire/ability to eat or drink, cognitive changes (delirium, increased sleep).
Middle Stage: Further mental decline, brief wakefulness, "death rattle" from mucus/saliva pooling due to weak cough reflex.
Late Stage: Fever, apnea, mottled skin from peripheral circulation loss; progression varies from 24 hrs to over 14 days.
Good Death: Typically pain-free, in a preferred location, surrounded by loved ones.

Clinical Death: Heart/lungs stop, but brain remains viable; timely CPR may restore function. Brain damage starts after 4 min without oxygen, death in 4-6 min.
Biologic Death (Brain Death): No brain activity or blood flow; diagnosed by apnea, absent brainstem reflexes, coma from known cause.
Causes of Biologic Death: Intracranial (subarachnoid hemorrhage, TBI) or extracranial (cardiac arrest, inadequate CPR, trauma, drowning, overdose, stroke, aneurysm).
Pathophysiology of Biologic Death: Brain oxygen deprivation → increased edema → raised intracranial pressure → reduced cerebral perfusion → herniation.
Organ Donation: Mechanical support can maintain lung/heart function, but brain death is required for organ donation eligibility.


General Changes: Profound weakness, fatigue, increased sleep, disorientation, visions of deceased individuals.
Food & Fluids: Decreased interest in eating/drinking, weight loss, dehydration, difficulty swallowing (choking/coughing).
Urinary Function: Decreased output, urinary incontinence, dark concentrated urine due to low fluid intake.
Skin Changes: Mottling (purple/dark pink in lighter skin, brown in darker skin), pressure injuries from immobility and poor perfusion.
Cardiac & Circulation Changes: Reduced cerebral perfusion (drowsiness, confusion, terminal delirium), peripheral cyanosis, mottling, hypotension, tachycardia, cooling extremities.
Respiratory Changes: Pooling secretions causing "death rattle," weak/absent cough reflex, dyspnea, Cheyne-Stokes respirations (shallow, rapid breathing with apnea periods).


Absence of resp, HR, responsiveness, voluntary movement, muscle function, and nervous system activity
Complete muscle relaxation
Algor mortis causes body cooling, pale skin, and loss of turgor
Rigor mortis causes muscle stiffness, beginning within 2-6 hours and peaking at 12 hours
Livor mortis causes blood pooling in dependent areas, leading to purple or reddish discoloration, which becomes fixed after 6-12 hours


Specialized care for clients with serious illnesses to improve quality of life.
Treatment Approach: Can include symptom management alongside or instead of curative treatments.
Client Support: Helps clients understand treatment options and make informed choices.
Interprofessional Team: Includes nurses, social workers, dietitians, chaplains, and providers; tailored to client needs.
Goals: Supports clients in living actively until death, focusing on comfort and symptom control.
Common Symptoms Managed: Dyspnea and pain are primary concerns.
Early Implementation Benefits: More effective when started early, reducing unnecessary hospitalizations. Palliative Sedation
Used for terminally ill or actively dying clients with distressing symptoms
Relieves pain, agitation, and anxiety to prevent unnecessary suffering
Not intended to hasten death
Common medications: opiates, benzodiazepines, antipsychotics
Risks: respiratory depression, aspiration, delirium-related agitation
Requires informed consent from the client or legal proxy
Must align with advanced directives if applicable


Definition: Focuses on comfort, quality of life, and support for clients nearing the end of life.
Eligibility: For clients with a terminal illness, typically with a prognosis of fewer than six months, though it can be extended.
Care Approach: Provides comfort care rather than curative treatment.
Settings: Can be provided at home, in hospitals, hospice centers, or nursing homes.
Interprofessional Team: Offers medical, emotional, physical, spiritual, and social support.
Home Hospice: Primarily managed by family and friends with hospice team support.
Respite Care: Temporary relief for caregivers to prevent burnout.
Nursing Role: Collaborates with clients, families, and the care team to honor patient wishes and provide education.
Palliative vs. Hospice Care Comparison

Palliative Care:
Provided alongside curative treatments or as symptom management
Can begin at any stage of a serious illness
Aims to improve quality of life and relieve symptoms
Available in hospitals, outpatient clinics, and nursing homes
Hospice Care:
For clients with a terminal illness, typically with a prognosis of ≤6 months
Focuses on comfort rather than curative treatment
Provided at home, in hospice centers, hospitals, or nursing homes
Primarily managed by family with hospice team support
Both:
Aim to improve quality of life
Use an interprofessional team for medical, emotional, social, and spiritual support
Manage symptoms such as pain and dyspnea
Respect client autonomy and end-of-life wishes





Identifying Potential Donors:
Clients must meet brain death criteria (irreversible loss of all brain function).
Brain death is confirmed through apnea, known-cause coma, and absent brainstem reflexes.
Clients near death (not brain dead) may still be assessed for potential donation.
Organs & Tissues Eligible for Donation:
Organs: Kidneys, liver, lungs, heart, pancreas, intestines.
Tissues: Corneas, middle ear, heart valves, bone, veins, ligaments, tendons, cartilage, skin.
Other Donations: Hands, face, bone marrow, cord blood, blood stem cells, blood, platelets.
Live Organ Donation: One kidney, one lung, part of the liver, pancreas, or intestine.
Assessment & Scoring:
CGS: Score of 3 with the absence of at least three brainstem reflexes indicates imminent brain death.
FOUR Score: Evaluates respiration, eye response, brainstem response, and motor response (score of 0 suggests brain death).
Nurse’s Role in Brain Death & Donation Process:
Assess and document brainstem reflexes and neurological status.
Maintain circulation and respiratory function with mechanical ventilation and vasopressors.
Work closely with the organ donation coordinator to evaluate donor suitability.
Shift care focus from treatment of the client to organ preservation.
Priorities in Donor Care:
Maintain a patent airway and normal body temperature.
Ensure adequate oxygenation and perfusion of organs.
Maintain fluid and electrolyte balance to prevent complications.
Family Communication & Support:
Nurses play a key role in discussing organ donation due to their relationship with the family.
Use clear, compassionate communication, explaining brain death and prognosis.
Respect cultural and spiritual beliefs regarding death and organ donation.
Families are more likely to consent when they experience compassion, commitment, and clear information.
Education & Training for Nurses:
Ongoing training on organ donation, brain death criteria, grief counseling, and facility protocols.
Sensitivity to the death and dying process is crucial.


Pain & Symptom Management: Assess and manage pain, dyspnea, agitation, and secretions using medications (opioids, benzodiazepines, anticholinergics).
Comfort Care: Reposition frequently, provide skin care, and use moisture barriers to prevent breakdown. Keep the client clean, dry, and comfortable.
Respiratory Support: Elevate the head of the bed, use oxygen if needed for comfort, and provide suctioning or anticholinergic medications for excessive secretions.
Emotional & Psychological Support: Offer reassurance, provide presence, and support the client and family emotionally. Encourage open discussions about end-of-life wishes.
Communication: Speak softly, use simple phrases, and ensure the client and family understand changes occurring. Provide honest but compassionate information.
Hydration & Nutrition: Do not force food or fluids; provide oral care to prevent dryness and cracking of lips. Use ice chips or moistened swabs for comfort.
Urinary & Bowel Care: Monitor for incontinence, use absorbent pads, provide perineal care, and consider catheterization if needed.
Skin Integrity: Turn and reposition frequently, use pressure-relieving devices, and assess for skin breakdown.
Cultural & Spiritual Considerations: Respect religious or cultural practices related to death and dying; involve chaplains or spiritual leaders as requested.
Family Support: Encourage family presence, educate about the dying process, and provide opportunities to say goodbye. Offer grief resources.
Postmortem Care: Respect cultural practices, clean the body, remove tubes (unless an autopsy is required), and prepare the body for the family’s final moments.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Perioperative Care
item.description:
#preop #periop #postop #nursing #medsurg
#preop #periop #postop #nursing #medsurg
check the ATI textbook as well

3 Phases:

preop - begins as soon as client is scheduled for surgery
intraop
postop - ends with transfer or discharge
Nurse primary role: advocate
Classification of Surgical Procedures:
By Purpose:

diagnostic
ablative - remove body part or tissue to destroy it (colectomy, removal of tumors)
palliative - provides relief/lessen pain
constructive - restore lost function that was present in birth
restorative/reconstructive - repair or restore a missing body part/organ
transplant
cosmetic
Seriousness:

major - risky
minor
Urgency:

emergent - ASAP, within minutes
urgent - life-saving, within hours of presentation
expedited - not emergency, within days
elective - not urgent, based on convenience
ASA Physical Class system

Class I-VI (healthy to braindead)
Class I - normal healthy adult
Class II - mild medical condition
Class V - critical condition who will die w/o procedure
Class VI - brain dead, organs to be donate
AORN Perioperative Patient Focused Model:

4 dimensions: Health System, Safety, Behavioral Responses and Physiological Responses.

Informed Consent:
- needs:
- procedure, potential risks, type of anesthesia, type of anesthesia, risk of anesthesia, any other potential procedures during surgery, postop plan, potential complications, risk and benefits, complications to client
- provider explains and obtains, nurse verifies and witnesses informed consent
- family member or guardian if patient is unconscious or mentally incompetent
Preop Tasks:

medical surgical hx obtained, check allergies
baseline head-to-to, VS, height, weight
prep skin: avoid shaving if possible
NPO and meds
hygiene, remove all jewelry
remove nail polish to notice signs of cyanosis
don surgical gown and cap, slippers
Preop Diagnostic Tests:

CBC, Hgb, Hct
Coags: PT, INR, aPTT, platelet
Metabolic: electrolyte, ck, BUN
HCG, urinalysis
CXR, ECG
Bloodtype & screen: if possibility of heavy bleeding (hip replacement)


phase start/end: operating table to PACU/ICU
Nurse role: circulating/scrub
know type of surgery & anesthesia
assist, client positioning
maintain aseptic environment, document, monitor complications


phase start/end: PACU until recovery from procedure
pain assessment- begins in preop stage to establish baseline pain
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS)

surgical protocol implemented to drive client-centered process postoperatively to improve client outcomes
must involve whole team
focuses: mobility, nutrition, pain, manage N/V, discontinue IV fluids ASAP, continue client education


begins in preop stage
teach specific equipment, medications, recovery exercises (breathing, coughing, spirometer, leg exercises, position changes), pain management, coping techniques, etc.
Diaphragm Breathing Exercise

lie supine, hands on stomach, inhale nose, exhale pursed lips, repeat 5 times
Deep Breathing Exercise

sit back, inhale 4 seconds nose, hold breath for 8 seconds, exhale 8 seconds pursed lips, repeat 3 times
Incentive Spirometer

sit, set goal marker, breath in, once goal reached, hold for as long as possible
exhale slowly, pause then repeat 10 times
done every hour for 10 times
Postop Education Topics:

proper nutrition
meds
lifestyle
wound care
follow-up


Malignant Hyperthermia - genetic disorder triggered by anesthesia/succinylcholines, life-threatening
treatment: dantrolene
tachycardia, tachypnea, cardiac arrhythmias, hyperkalemia, hypercarbia, and muscular rigidity.
Note: postop clients are at increased risk of:
delayed wound healing
infection
increased length of stay
aspiration
DVT
Note: OSA = higher risk of difficult intubation
Note: PACU priority: maintain airway and respiratory status
Note: cardiac postop = increased risk for hypothermia
Dehiscence Treatment: cover with sterile dressing soaked in saline and then notify provider
prevention: limit vomiting, coughing, constipation
Aldrete Score - scoring system determines if patient can be safely discharged from PACU
must be 8-10 for discharge
criteria: oxygenation, RR, circulation, LOC, activity


similar to periop nursing
nurse provides support, care, fluids, and blood if ordered and monitors the client closely for organ rejection
Note precautions: immunocompromised from the medications and procedures
Note: critical time in first 24 hours after transplant
main complication: rejection of organ
Types of Organ Rejection:

Hyperacute rejection - minutes or hours after transplantation, caused by antibodies
Acute rejection - caused by certain lymphocytes that detect antigens in the transplanted tissue or organ days or weeks after transplantation
Chronic rejection - months or years following organ or tissue transplantation.

item.title: Fractures
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Osteoporosis
item.description:
the rate of bone resorption (osteoclast cells) exceeds the rate of bone formation (osteoblast cells)
results in fragile bone tissue and can lead to fractures
Chronic, progressive bone disease characterized by low bone mass and deterioration of bone tissue
Often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs
Osteopenia - precursor to osteoporosis; low bone mineral density relative to the client’s age and sex; bone density peaks at 18-30, decreases gradually, significant decrease in postmenopausal women


Aging (natural loss of bone mass over time)
Hormonal changes (especially estrogen deficiency in postmenopausal women)
Males: loss of testosterone => decreased bone mass
Nutritional deficiencies (calcium, vitamin D)

Non-Modifiable:

Female sex (higher risk than males)
Aging (risk increases after 50)
Family history of osteoporosis or fractures
Caucasian or Asian ethnicity
History of malabsorption disorders (celiac disease, anorexia, bariatric surgery)
Modifiable:

Low calcium and vitamin D intake
Sedentary lifestyle (lack of weight-bearing exercise)
Excess alcohol (decreased bone formation and increased bone absorption)
Excess Caffeine consumption => increased excretion of calcium in the urine.
Smoking (reduces bone mass)
Long-term corticosteroid use (e.g., prednisone)
Low body weight or eating disorders
high protein or low protein diet


Often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs
Loss of height over time (due to vertebral compression fractures)
Kyphosis (hunched back, "dowager’s hump")
Back pain from vertebral fractures
Fragility fractures (hip, wrist, vertebrae) from minimal trauma


Fractures (hip, spine, and wrist most common)
Chronic pain and disability from fractures
Loss of independence (due to mobility issues)
Increased mortality (hip fractures linked to higher mortality rates)


Bone Mineral Density (BMD) Testing (via DEXA scan); T-score ≤ -2.5 confirms osteoporosis
Serum calcium, vitamin D levels (to assess deficiencies)
X-rays (for fractures)
24 hr urine = check

Lifestyle Modifications:

Increase calcium intake (1200 mg/day postmenopausal women)
Vitamin D supplements (800-1000 IU/day) => increased calcium absorption
Weight-bearing exercises (walking, resistance training)
Smoking cessation & limiting alcohol intake
limit caffeine
Medications:

Bisphosphonates (first-line):
Alendronate, risedronate, zoledronic acid (inhibit bone resorption)
Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators (SERMs) (e.g., raloxifene) => replace estrogen due to menopause (note: high risk of breast, endo cancer, DVT)
Denosumab (monoclonal antibody) for high-risk patients
Calcitonin (less commonly used)
Parathyroid hormone analogs (teriparatide) (stimulates bone formation)
Orthotic Devices - immobilization of the spine immediately after a compression fracture of the spine
Surgery: joint repair, vertebroplasty, kyphoplasty


Educate on fall prevention (home safety modifications, proper footwear, clear walkways, adequate lighting, etc)
Encourage weight-bearing and resistance exercises
Monitor for signs of fractures (sudden pain, loss of function)
Ensure adequate calcium and vitamin D intake
Teach correct administration of bisphosphonates (take on an empty stomach with water, stay upright for 30-60 min)


Risk for injury related to fragile bones
Impaired physical mobility due to pain or fractures
Chronic pain related to vertebral fractures
Deficient knowledge related to disease management and prevention

item.title: Sprains
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Alzheimers
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting memory, thinking, behavior
most common cause of Dementia
amyloid plaque buildup and neurofibrillary tangles in brain
leads to gradual loss of cognitive and functional abilities


Age (most cases occur after age 65)
Family history and genetics
Cardiovascular disease (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia)
Head trauma and traumatic brain injury (TBI)
Chronic stress and depression
Sedentary lifestyle and poor diet


same as Dementia
depends on the stage:
Early stage: Mild Alzheimer's

Short-term memory loss (misplacing items, forgetting names)
Difficulty finding words and making decisions
Mild confusion and disorientation
Middle/Moderate stage:

Increased memory loss and difficulty recognizing loved ones
Behavioral changes (agitation, aggression, mood swings)
Wandering and getting lost
Difficulty with complex tasks (managing finances, cooking)
Late/Severe stage:

Severe cognitive decline and loss of communication
body begins to completely shut down
Inability to perform self-care (feeding, dressing, toileting)
Loss of mobility, swallowing difficulties, and incontinence



Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) shorter, longer: Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) - first-line neuro exam, administer several times across time
amyloid beta protein precursor (soluble) - identifies gene mutations causing early-onset
MRI/CT - rule out other conditions
PET scan - detect amyloid plaque buildup



maintain quiet environment
Ensure a safe environment (fall prevention, door alarms for wandering)**
Use simple communication (speak slowly, use short sentences)
Provide structured routines (minimizes confusion and anxiety)
Assist with activities of daily living (ADLs) as disease progresses
Encourage social interaction and cognitive activities
Monitor for signs of infection, dehydration, and malnutrition
Support and educate caregivers on disease progression
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Delirium
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

Acute, reversible cognitive disturbance characterized by confusion, disorientation, and impaired attention
Develops suddenly over hours to days
Fluctuating course with periods of lucidity and confusion
Often secondary to an underlying medical condition
Compared to Dementia:
Dementia: gradual onset, worsens over time
Delirium: sudden, sporadic manifestations (on and off)


Hypoxia (e.g., respiratory failure, cardiac conditions)
Infections (e.g., UTI, Pneumonia, sepsis)
Metabolic imbalances (e.g., Fluid & Electrolyte ATI, electrolyte disturbances, Hypoglycemia)
Medications (e.g., opioids, benzodiazepines, anticholinergics)
Substance withdrawal (e.g., alcohol, benzodiazepines)
Head trauma or surgery (especially in older adults)
Sleep deprivation and sensory deprivation
prolonged heat or sun exposure


Older adults (especially those with dementia)
Hospitalization, ICU stays
Polypharmacy
History of substance use
Severe illness or chronic conditions
Visual or hearing impairment


Acute onset of confusion and disorientation
Fluctuating levels of consciousness (periods of alertness alternating with drowsiness)
Impaired attention and concentration
Disorganized thinking and incoherent speech
Hallucinations or delusions (often visual)
Agitation, restlessness, or lethargy
Sleep-wake cycle disturbances (e.g., nighttime confusion, daytime drowsiness)


Increased fall risk (due to confusion and agitation)
Aspiration pneumonia (from decreased swallowing ability)
Longer hospital stays and functional decline
Progression to dementia in vulnerable individuals


Clinical assessment (based on sudden onset and fluctuating symptoms)
Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) (screens for delirium)
Blood glucose: rule out Hyperglycemia/Hypoglycemia
Drug screen
Urinalysis: rule out UTI
Rue out e-/fluid imbalance: CMP

Neuroimaging (MRI, CT scan) (if head trauma or stroke is suspected)


Identify and treat underlying cause (e.g., antibiotics for infection, fluids for dehydration)
Medications (only if severe agitation; e.g., low-dose haloperidol or atypical antipsychotics)
Environmental modifications (quiet, well-lit room, familiar objects, reorientation cues)
Adequate hydration, nutrition, and oxygenation
Promote regular sleep-wake cycle


Monitor for sudden changes in mental status
Reorient frequently (provide clocks, calendars, family photos)
Ensure safety (fall precautions, avoid restraints)
Encourage family presence (reduces anxiety and confusion)
Minimize use of sedatives and anticholinergic medications
Promote mobility and engagement (helps prevent worsening symptoms)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Dementia
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

Progressive decline in cognitive function, affecting memory, reasoning, language, and problem-solving
Types:

Vascular Dementia - reduced oxygen to brain from altered vasculature
Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) - protein deposits in brain block neuron connections
Fronto-Temporal dementia (FTD) - affects frontal lobe causing changes in behavior
Mixed Dementia - self-explanatory


Alzheimers - most common cause


advanced age
brain injury
Alzheimers
cardiovascular disease
neurodegenerative diseases: Huntington's, Wernicke-Korsakoff
poor diet, lack of physical activity
smoking, alcohol


memory loss
changes in judgement, problem solving
confusion
wandering
getting lost
changes in speaking & language
inability to express or understand thots & words
difficulty performing daily tasks
hallucinations or delusions


Malnutrition and dehydration (due to forgetting to eat or drink)
Increased fall risk (due to impaired coordination and judgment)
Infections (e.g., pneumonia, urinary tract infections)
Wandering and getting lost
Loss of ability to perform self-care (requiring full-time assistance)
Aspiration pneumonia (due to swallowing difficulties)
depression, anxiety, social isolation


Clinical assessment and history-taking (evaluating cognitive decline)
Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) or Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA)
Neuroimaging (MRI, CT scan to rule out other causes)
Blood tests (to check for reversible causes like vitamin deficiencies, infections, or thyroid disorders)
CSF analysis (for suspected neurodegenerative conditions)


goal: maintain independence (work with ST=swallowing, OT = ADL, PT=mobility, Psych=feels)
no cure but meds can slow progression or manage symptoms
Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) for mild-to-moderate dementia
NMDA receptor antagonists (e.g., memantine) for moderate-to-severe cases
Antipsychotics, antidepressants, and mood stabilizers (for behavioral symptoms if necessary)
Cognitive therapy and memory training
Lifestyle modifications (healthy diet, exercise, social engagement)


provide calm and positive environment
remove hazards, use alarms for wandering prevention
maintain structured routines (avoid confusion and anxiety
speak slowly
monitor: depression, agitation, aggression
ensure nutrition and hydration

item.description:

#nursing #medsurg #neuro

item.title: Aneurysms
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro


weakening or bulging area in the wall of a cerebral artery
typically asymptomatic but can rupture causing life-threatening subarachnoid hemorrhage
commonly located at arterial bifurcations in the Circle of Willis
most aneurysms do not rupture


hypertension => increased vessel wall stress
Atherosclerosis (weakens vessel walls)
Congenital arterial defects (e.g. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD))
Head trauma
Infections (mycotic aneurysms)
Connective tissue disorders (Ehlers-Danlos, Marfan syndrome)


family hx
smoking - damaged blood vessels
alcohol or drug abuse
age >40


sudden severe headache
Stroke presentation
N/V
visual disurbances
stiff neck
confusion
seizure
LOC
Cardiac Arrest
Death
Unruptured CA: sometimes none, double vision, pain behind eye, dilated pupil, numbness on one side of face


MRI, CT, CTA
Cerebral Angiogram - small catheter is inserted in vessel in leg all the way to brain, guided by x-ray
Lumbar Puncture - presence of blood in CSF (+)


ruptured: need surgical intervention ASAP, life-threatening
unruptured or no manifestations: no treatment required, monitor
unruptured but large and symptomatic: surgical intervention or endovascular therapy
surgical clipping - metal clip punches the aneurysm
Endovascular therapy: stent or mesh barrier is inserted to induce a clot, blocking blood to aneurysm


Monitor neurological status (LOC, pupils, motor function)
Maintain BP within target range (avoid hypotension/hypertension)
Keep HOB elevated 30 degrees to reduce ICP
Minimize stimulation (quiet environment, limit visitors)
Implement seizure precautions
Educate on lifestyle modifications (BP control, smoking cessation, avoiding stimulants)
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cerebral Edema
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

swelling of brain
can be fatal
results in herniation = swelling exerts pressure on brain (ICP), blood restriction induces hypoxia


TBI / concussion
Stroke
Brain Tumors or abscesses
Interstitial Shift: CSF increased, hydrocephalus, Meningitis, encephalitis
Osmotic Shift/Edema: DKA, hyponatremia
High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE)
Carbon Monoxide poisoning
Reye's syndrome
lead poisoning
Hepatitis (Ammonia buildup in bloodstream causes brain swelling)


uncontrolled BP
smoking
Diabetes => DKA
activities that result in high risk for falls


headache (most common)
neck rigidity/pain
Cushing's Triad => 1. hypertension, 2. brady, 3. irregular respirations
N/V
dizziness
respiratory pattern changes
vision changes
ataxia - lack of muscle coordination, balance
aphasia - inability to speak or understand speecj
seizure
LOC
pupil changes
CN deficit


increased ICP, leads to herniation
coma, brains stem compression
respiratory failure


CT/MRI - determine midline shift, herniation
ICP monitoring - invasive procedure
CBC - e-
LP


goal: decrease hypertension, control edema, decrease ICP
Surgical: removal of tumors/lesions, shunt insertion, damaged vessel repair
hyperbaric oxygen therapy
hypertonic IVF to decrease CE
Induced hypothermia to redice swelling
Ventriculostomy - drain CSF
Diuretics - reduce swelling (i.e. osmotic diuretics such as mannitol, hypertonic saline)
glucocorticoids - reduce swelling
induced coma
anticonvulsants


monitor GCS & pupil response - detect deterioration
maintain HOB @ 30 deg
avoid excessive stimulation: loud noises, bright lights, frequent repositioning
Avoid HTN
Prevent fever: increases metabolic demand and ICP
Avoid dehydration and HYPOnatermia: worsens CE
Prepare for intubation if brainstem compression worsens
Prepare for seizures
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Head Injuries
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

broad term that refers to any damage to the head due to trauma
can cause TBI => alteration in neuro function
Types (for other types, go to Critical Care section: TBI)

Concussion - mild head injury that may or may not cause a temporary loss of consciousness
Subdural Hematoma - collection of blood between the brain and dura
Monro-Kellie Doctrine - cranial vault is composed blood, brain tissue, CSF (if one of these swells, the other must decrease, otherwise, will result in increased ICP)

Total Score: 3 (lowest) to 15 (highest)

13-15 = Mild brain injury
9-12 = Moderate brain injury
≤8 = Severe brain injury (coma)


MVA
Falls: d/t old age, visual acuity, weakness, chronic hypertension, meds
physical assault
Type of trauma: blunt, penetrating, blast

Concussion Manifestations - may appear abruptly or within days

headache
confusion
difficulty concentrating
N/V
dizziness
blurred vision
fatigue
amnesia of the event that caused injury
Acute Subdural Hematoma (SDH) Manifestations

change in consciousness; memory loss, disorientation
altered pupil response
hemiparesis
severe: HTN, bradycardia, bradypnea, comatose
Chronic SDH

can manifest weeks to months after initial injury
PCS - Post Concussive Syndrome

when manifestations persists for more than 3 months
such as headache, photosensitivity, dizziness, and fatigue


increased ICP
brain herniation
seizures
Hydrocephalus - CSF accumulation
permanent disability
death


full neuro exam: check reflexes, sensation, strength, visual acuity
Affective/emotional: changes in mood, irritability
Cognitive: difficulty concentrating, amnesia, confusion, brain fog
Physical/Somatic: visual disturbances, headaches, dizziness
Sleep: trouble, drowsiness, sleep alteration
Imaging: CT (most common), MRI, XR
CMP, Coags (check PT/INR, PTT)


Mild Head Injury: supportive care only, discontinue activities, analgesia, observation if at risk (e.g. bleeding disorder, anticoagulants)
Small SDH: few or no neuro concerns: rest and observation, clot will be absorbed in months, no long-term complications
Large SDH: surgical to remove hematoma, ICP monitoring
Rehab


fall precautions
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Headaches
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro


pain from stretching, constriction, dilation, or nociceptor stimulation of muscle fibers, meninges, facial structures, blood vessels, or cranial or spinal nerves
varies in location, intensity (sharp, throbbing, or a dull ache)
Primary Headaches - not caused by other conditions; examples: migraines, cluster headaches, tension-type headaches (TTH)
Secondary - caused by other conditions such as trauma, infections, ICP, vascular disorders, etc
Migraines - recurrent headaches that last for four to 72 hr; from change in cerebral perfusion; not fully understood
Status Migrainosis - lasts for more than 72 hours


Head trauma
Caffeine
Foods containing nitrates or tyramine
Artificial sweeteners
Hormonal changes
Bright lights
Strong odors
Changes in weather
Stress
Skipping meals


Carbon monoxide poisoning
Cerebrovascular Accident
Intracranial hemorrhage (see Subarachnoid Hemorrhage - blood in space under the arachnoid membrane, most commonly from trauma/rupture of an aneurysm)
Hypertension emergencies
Meningitis
Encephalitis
Acute angle-closure glaucoma
Brain tumor



mild/moderate pain on both sides of head
dull/band-like pressure
Muscle tightness in the shoulder, neck, or back
associated with sleep disturbances
lasts 30 min to 7 days


Severe unilateral head pain, often behind the eye
Lacrimation, nasal congestion, eyelid/facial swelling, ptosis may occur (ptosis - drooping eyelid)
Excruciating, nonfluctuating pain; clients may pace or rock
Duration: 15 min to hours, may occur multiple times daily

Prodormal Phase (Hours to Days Before Headache)

Sensitivity to light, sound, odor
Fatigue, yawning
Food cravings, excessive thirst
Mood swings
Constipation or diarrhea
Aura Phase (Lasts ~60 min, Precedes Headache, Reversible Symptoms, Affects ~25%)

Visual, sensory, motor disturbances
Tunnel vision, blindness, visual field loss
Heaviness in limbs
Speech/language disturbances
Scintillating scotoma
Tingling in face/limbs
Headache Phase (Unilateral, Throbbing, Lasts Hours to Days, >72 hr = Status Migrainosus)

Nausea/vomiting
Photophobia, phonophobia => sensitivity to light and sound
Rhinorrhea, lachrymation
Loss of appetite, fatigue
Postdromal Phase ("Migraine Hangover," Lasts 1–2 Days)

Pain with movement in migraine location
Exhaustion, dizziness
Difficulty concentrating
Euphoria




none; usually
MRI/CT - for older than 50 with no hx, if present with hypertension or AMS
Lumbar Puncture - analyze CSF for Meningitis


Analgesia - usually OTC: aspirin, aceta, NSAID
Caffeine with analgesics
Opioids NOT recommended
Pharmacological treatments - only for headaches 3-15 times/month
Triptans - constrict intracranial vessels (e.g.: Sumatriptans, razatiptan) see Migraines pharm section
Anticonvulscants - valpiruc acid, topiramate
beta blockers
tricyclic antidepressants
botulinum toxins
IV fluids
steroids
non pharm: biofeedback, CBT, chiropractor, assage, craniosacal therapy, yoga, accupuntcture


ensure dark, quiet room
NOTE: if patient complains that it is their WORST HEADACHE, assess for secondary headache to rule out life-threats

avoid: cheese, meats with nitrites, aspartame, pickled foods, MSG
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: ICP
item.description:
Increased pressure within the skull due to brain swelling, excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), or bleeding
Can lead to brain herniation and death if untreated
Normal ICP: 5-15 mmHg; Critical ICP: >20 mmHg


TBI
Stroke
Brain Tumors
Hydrocephalus - increased CSF accumulation
Cerebral Edema - head trauma, hypoxia, liver failure (ammonia buildup)
Intracranial Hemorrhage
Severe Hypertension


Head trauma (falls, car accidents, assaults)
Aneurysm rupture (subarachnoid hemorrhage)
Severe infections (meningitis, encephalitis)
Brain tumors or metastases
Congenital conditions (hydrocephalus, Arnold-Chiari malformation)
Liver failure (risk of cerebral edema from ammonia buildup)

Early Signs:

altered LOC: confusion, restlessness, drowsiness
Headache (worsens with movement, coughing, or straining)
Blurred vision, diplopia (double vision)
N/V
Late Signs (Cushing’s Triad - Brainstem Compression):

Hypertension with widening pulse pressure
Bradycardia (slow heart rate)
Irregular respirations (Cheyne-Stokes or Biot’s breathing)
Other signs:

Papilledema (swelling of optic disc)
Pupil changes (unequal, sluggish, or fixed/dilated)
Posturing: decorticate (flexion), decerebrate (extension)
seizures


Brain herniation (fatal displacement of brain tissue)
Permanent neurological deficits (motor, sensory, cognitive impairments)
Seizures
Coma and death


CT scan/MRI (detect swelling, bleeding, tumors, hydrocephalus)
ICP monitoring (ventriculostomy, intraparenchymal device)
Lumbar puncture contraindicated if increased ICP is suspected (risk of brain herniation)
Fundoscopic exam (papilledema)


Reduce ICP and prevent complications
Elevate head of bed (HOB) 30 degrees (promotes venous drainage)
Oxygen therapy (maintain cerebral oxygenation)
Mechanical ventilation (if necessary) – PaCO₂ 30-35 mmHg to reduce cerebral blood flow
Surgery: craniotomy, external ventricular drain (EVD) to drain excess CSF, decompressive craniectomy (remove park of skull)
Medications:

Osmotic diuretics (mannitol) – reduces cerebral edema
Hypertonic saline (3%) – pulls fluid out of brain cells
Corticosteroids (dexamethasone) – for tumors, inflammation
Sedatives (propofol, benzodiazepines) – decrease metabolic demand
Antiepileptics – prevent seizures
Neuromuscular blockers (for severe cases requiring intubation)


Monitor LOC and Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) (↓ GCS = worsening ICP)
Assess pupil reaction (PERRLA) and vital signs frequently
Maintain head and neck alignment (avoid flexion or turning head)
Minimize stimulation (low lights, quiet room)
Avoid straining (stool softeners, prevent coughing/sneezing)
Cluster nursing care to minimize ICP spikes
Seizure precautions (padded rails, oxygen, suction at bedside)
Monitor for signs of herniation (fixed dilated pupils, loss of reflexes, coma)

#nursing #medsurg #neuro
see Meningitis in Inflammation section
